{"uri": "8118251086", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:40:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:40:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:39:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/team-diana-back-harry-at-invictus-anniversary-as-her-brother-earl-spencer-and-her-sister-lady-jane-fellowes-lead-guests-in-support-of-the-dukes-project/", "title": "Team Diana back Harry at Invictus anniversary as her brother Earl Spencer and her sister Lady Jane Fellowes lead guests in support of the Duke's project", "body": "Princess Diana's siblings were quick to show their support for Prince Harry during the Invictus Games anniversary service yesterday, while the royal family kept their distance - despite only being a few miles away.\n\nThe late Princess of Wales' younger brother Earl Spencer and elder sister Lady Jane Fellowes walked in side-by-side to St Paul's before chatting to their now US-based nephew.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex had cut a lonely figure as he climbed the steps of the cathedral - unaccompanied by his wife Meghan Markle, who remained in California with their two children.\n\nMeanwhile King Charles, who was invited to attend the service in central London, held the first garden party of the season at Buckingham Palace.\n\nThe monarch was joined by Queen Camilla, the Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh, the Princess Royal and the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester for the first of the summer festivities.\n\nThe only senior royals missing were the Prince and Princess of Wales. William was handing out awards in Windsor, while Kate is still undergoing treatment for cancer.\n\nPrince Harry's spokesperson had claimed on Tuesday the King had been too busy to see his youngest son during his fleeting visit to the UK.\n\nLast night, however, Palace sources suggested no formal requests for a meeting had been made.\n\nPrincess Diana 's siblings were quick to show their support for Prince Harry yesterday during the Invictus Games anniversary service yesterday. Pictured: The Duke of Sussex leaving St Paul's\n\nThe late Princess of Wales ' younger brother Earl Spencer and elder sister Lady Jane Fellowes walked in side-by-side to St Paul's\n\nMeanwhile King Charles , who was invited to attend the service in central London, held the first garden party of the season at Buckingham Palace\n\nPrincess Diana 's younger brother Charles Spencer arrives at St Paul's Cathedral ahead of the ceremony\n\nLady Jane maintains a close relationship with nephew Harry and was one of the first to meet his son Archie. Pictured here with Earl Spencer (right) at the unveiling of Diana's statue in 2021\n\nCharles Spencer, Princess Diana, then Prince Charles, Lady Jane Fellowes and Lady Sarah McCorquodale in 1985\n\nDespite well-documented tensions with the Windsors, Prince Harry has remained close to his mother's family over the years - particularly Lady Jane.\n\nLady Jane, the middle of the three sisters, four years older than Diana, has long been seen as a confidante and a steadying influence in his life.\n\nShe was asked to give a reading during Harry's wedding to Meghan in 2018 and was one of the first members to be invited to meet their infant son Archie - even before Prince William.\n\nThroughout his bombshell memoir Spare, he gave a 'stand out thanks' to Lady Jane, her elder sister Lady Sarah McCorquodale and Earl Spencer but failed to mention the late Queen, King Charles or his brother.\n\nIt is therefore little surprise that two of the siblings turned out at yesterday's ceremony to give support to Diana's youngest child.\n\nAs well as his aunt and uncle, Harry was surrounded by a number of dignitaries, politicians and close friends.\n\nHis lawyer David Sherbourne was in attendance while former army officer Mark Dyer - who helped mentor Harry particularly after his mother's death - was also in the congregation.\n\nRishi Sunak's wife Akshata Murty also joined the group, dressed in a military-style green coat with gold buttons, where she was joined by Minister of State for Veterans' Affairs Johnny Mercer.\n\nPrince Harry put on a brave face today as he left St Paul's Cathedral alone following a service to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games\n\nThe 9th Earl Spencer can be seen smiling and gesticulating as he walks up the steps to the historic English landmark\n\nThe estranged royal, who was met with cheers from the crowd, beamed as he shook hands and joked around with dozens of people who had lined up to greet him\n\nGuests attending the royal garden party at Buckingham Palace in London this afternoon\n\nOther stars within the crowd included former Olympic champion triple jumper Jonathan Edwards.\n\nHuge crowds had gathered outside St Paul's to catch a glimpse of the estranged royals rare appearance on British soil, with some shouting 'we love you Harry' as he walked out of his car.\n\nThe Duke was warmly greeted by the Dean of St Paul's, the Very Reverend Andrew Tremlett, before being escorted to his seat under the cathedral's great dome.\n\nWhilst inside the cathedral he spoke to the clergy, as well as Earl Spencer before taking his seat.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex, who remains estranged from many family members after a string of attacks on the Royal Family in recent years, said on Tuesday that he had been told his father did not have time to see him this week while he is staying in the UK.\n\nCharles had not been able to find time to see his son Prince Harry this afternoon as he attends the first Buckingham Palace garden party of the summer season.\n\nThe King had a busy day yesterday with meetings planned in the morning ahead of the garden party. He then attended his weekly audience with the Prime Minister in the evening followed by a Privy Council meeting.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex has flown into London for the Invictus engagements and there were hopes that he would see the King. But a spokesman for Harry said that the monarch's 'full programme' meant the get-together would not happen.\n\nPrince Harry, Duke of Sussex waves as he arrives to attend a ceremony marking the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games\n\nBritain's Minister of State for Veterans' Affairs Johnny Mercer (L) and Akshata Murty, wife of Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, arrive to attend the ceremony\n\nDavid Sherborne, Britain's Prince Harry's lawyer, arrives at St Paul's this afternoon\n\nFormer Army officer Mark Dyer, who acted as the duke's mentor, playing the role of a supportive big brother figure for Harry after Diana's death, arrives at the ceremony\n\nYet royal insiders last night told the Telegraph that no formal requests for a meeting with the King had been made.\n\nDuring the ceremony Harry took a seat next to his mentor Mark Dyer and exchanged a few words with his uncle Earl Spencer.\n\nThe service began with the hymn Praise My Soul The King Of Heaven as a few miles away the King hosted the first Buckingham Palace garden party of the year.\n\nThe Dean of St Paul's told the congregation: 'We gather this evening to offer grateful thanksgiving to Almighty God for the work of the Invictus Games Foundation, and in this their 10th anniversary year, we celebrate the tremendous achievements of the numerous competitors across 23 nations.\n\n'We give thanks for the inspiring vision and compassion that formed the foundation and, chiefly, for the resultant decade of profound and transformational work.\n\n'We lament the pain, cost and indignity of war and terror, and pray for a world where justice shall reign and where the nations will find their longed for unity.\n\n'We recall, with admiration, the skill and determination of those who seek to repair, rehabilitate, and reclaim the lives of those living with serious illness or injury: changing and saving lives.'\n\nHe gave a reading from 1 Corinthians 12 4-11. Actor Damian Lewis, 53, meanwhile read out the Invictus poem with the service being conducted by William Ernest Henley.\n\nAn emotional reading was also given by Michelle Turner who is the UK Invictus Games Team vice-captain. She read a personal poem about how the games had helped her recovery and impacted her family.\n\nOther stars among the crowd included former Olympic champion triple jumper Jonathan Edwards\n\nMembers of the public wait to see Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex arrive to attend the ceremony\n\nAt the end of the reading she tearfully said: 'Thank you Invictus, for giving me my life back.'\n\nAs he left the cathedral on a balmy evening in the capital, the Californian-based royal greeted large crowds.\n\nHe was heard asking two fans from New York what had brought them to the UK. When they responded they were here for a wedding, the Prince jokingly asked it was 'in there?' referring to St Paul's Cathedral.\n\nThe Duke joked around with one enthusiastic royal fan who had her arms outstretched with two phones to try and get the best shot of Harry.\n\n'Why have you got 2 phones?' he laughed, 'it doesn't make sense!'\n\nHundreds of people had joined the crowd that was tightly guarded by police officers.\n\nShouts of 'we love you Harry' could be heard as the Prince did his walkabout, while others screamed with excitement until Harry got into a Land Rover and drove off.\n\nPrince Harry arrives to attend the Invictus Games Foundation 10th Anniversary Service of Thanksgiving at St Paul's Cathedral\n\nKing Charles III speaks to guests as he hosts a Royal Garden Party at Buckingham Palace in central London\n\nHarry arriving at St Paul's Cathedral for a service to celebrate the 10th anniversary of his Invictus Games\n\nThe Duke joked around with one enthusiastic royal fan who had her arms outstretched with two phones to try and get the best shot of Harry\n\nKing Charles III speaks to guests attending the garden party at Buckingham Palace today\n\nIt is not known where Harry is staying while in Britain as he now has no official home after being asked to leave Frogmore Cottage.\n\nHe is expected to stay in the UK until tomorrow before flying to Nigeria where he will meet up with Meghan for a quasi-royal tour that is also expected to highlight the Invictus Games.\n\nHarry spent Tuesday in the capital attending a summit that reflected on the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games, which stages sporting events for wounded, sick or injured veterans or serving military to aid their recovery.\n\nHe told delegates at the event, held at the Honourable Artillery Company's headquarters on the edge of the City of London: 'Sometimes you... look back and go 'Look at what we've done'.\n\n'But also given the state of the world, there is so much more to do and I think a lot of uncertainty - but what we've created is a global community.'\n\nKing Charles III (centre) and Queen Camilla walk out to join the crowds at the Royal Garden Party at Buckingham Palace\n\nAkshata Murty arrives at the Invictus Games in a military-style green coat with gold buttons\n\nCharles Spencer arrives to attend his nephew's ceremony marking the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games\n\nBarrister David Sherborne arrives to attend a ceremony marking the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games\n\nMembers of the public wait outside St Paul's Cathedral in London, ahead of the arrival of the Duke of Sussex\n\nA woman waits with her head slumped in her hand as she waits for Harry to arrive at St Paul's\n\nPrince Harry, Duke of Sussex wears his medals as he attends the Invictus Games Foundation's 10th Anniversary celebration\n\nThe King, Queen, Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh, the Princess Royal and the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester arrive together for the garden party\n\nKing Charles III speaks to guests attending a Royal Garden Party at Buckingham Palace\n\nQueen Camilla speaks to guests attending a Royal Garden Party at Buckingham Palace\n\nHarry is also not expected to see his estranged brother Prince William who held an investiture ceremony at Windsor Castle yesterday.\n\nWilliam continues to balance work with looking after his three children while his wife Kate undergoes preventative chemotherapy for cancer and recovers from serious abdominal surgery in January.\n\nToday William will fly to Cornwall for further official engagements - and the King will meet staff and families of the 3 Royal School of Military Engineering in Surrey.\n\nThen on Monday there will be a rare joint visit for Charles and William, as the King officially hands over the role of Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps to William at the Army Aviation Centre in Middle Wallop, where Harry previously learnt to fly.\n\nHarry has travelled to the UK to commemorate the Invictus Games milestone with those who have been involved with the paralympic-style tournament and mark the decade-long support competitors have received.\n\nCharles and Harry last met soon after the King announced his cancer diagnosis in February and his son rushed from America to see his father.\n\nThat was the first time Harry had seen his father in person for 17 months, and they had a half-hour meeting before Charles left London to recuperate at Sandringham following treatment.\n\nBut this time, a spokesman for Harry said: 'In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme.\n\nThe Duke was warmly greeted by the Dean of St Paul's, the Very Reverend Andrew Tremlett, before being escorted to his seat under the cathedral's great dome\n\nMark Dyer during The Invictus Games Foundation 10th Anniversary Service at St Paul's Cathedral\n\nRishi Sunak's wife Akshata Murty arrives at St Paul's for the Invictus ceremony\n\nDavid Sherborne, Britain's Prince Harry's lawyer, arrives to attend the Invictus Games Foundation 10th Anniversary Service of Thanksgiving\n\n'The duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.'\n\nJust hours after Harry's statement, palace officials announced a new joint engagement for Charles and William.\n\nIt is one of dozens of official engagements being planned for the 75-year-old monarch in the coming months after his doctors gave him the all-clear to undertake more public work once again while continuing his cancer treatment.\n\nOn Monday, Charles met the prime minister of the Republic of Fiji at Buckingham Palace, before retiring to Clarence House - three miles away from Harry's event.\n\nHarry now lives with his wife Meghan Markle and {"uri": "8119684156", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:23:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:23:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:22:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.sentinelandenterprise.com/2024/05/09/it-looks-like-king-charles-is-done-with-harry-palace-gates-firmly-closed/", "title": "It looks like King Charles is done with 'difficult' Harry: 'Palace gates firmly closed'", "body": "Royal watchers opined that Harry was 'snubbed' and that the king was sending an 'ominous' message by failing to schedule time to see him when he's in London\n\nPrince Harry's team subtly but surely conveyed the hurt he feels that his father, King Charles III, wouldn't make time to see him when he was in London this week for a 10th anniversary celebration of the Invictus Games.\n\nSure, there was a diplomatic statement from Harry's spokesperson about the two men having supposed scheduling conflicts during the Duke of Sussex's three-day trip to London. Arriving from California Tuesday, Harry had some meetings, then arrived at St Paul's Cathedral Wednesday for the Invictus Games anniversary.\n\nMeanwhile on Wednesday, Charles hosted a garden party at Buckingham Palace, then was scheduled to have an audience with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and a Privy Council meeting. He's also had hospital appointments for his ongoing treatment for cancer.\n\nIn a statement, Harry's spokesperson said that a meeting between the two was \"unfortunately ... not possible due to His Majesty's full program,\" The Telegraph reported. The spokesman also said that Harry is \"understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nWhether Harry really is \"understanding\" may never be known -- until anonymous \"insider\" sources from either his camp or from Buckingham Palace leak behind-the-scenes observations to the media. But royal watchers definitely opined Wednesday that Harry was \"snubbed\" and that his father was sending him an \"ominous\" message.\n\nCharles' unwillingness to schedule even 15 minutes to see his estranged son this week, after Harry traveled all the way from California, is an indication that \"the palace gates remain firmly closed,\" said journalist and author Richard Kay. The relationship between Harry and with his father and the rest of the royal family appears to be \"more broken than ever,\" Kay also said.\n\nRoyal expert Michael Cole agreed, telling the Daily Mail: \"It is quite a snub. For the king to not see his younger son, although the two men will be only two miles apart (Wednesday), gives an indication of the depth of the divide.\"\n\n\"The prodigal son is not welcome -- not for the present, anyway,\" Cole continued. \"In royal terms, this is big medicine. Prince Harry is bound to see it for what it is, the clearest possible indication of the hurt that has been caused.\"\n\nPiers Morgan, a fierce critic of Harry and his wife, Meghan Markle, was even more blunt about \"the snub,\" writing in The Sun: \"Let's be honest: if Charles had really wanted to see him, he'd have made the time. That's the whole point of being a king, you get to do what the hell you like.\"\n\nBut Morgan said it's clear from the statements about \"scheduling\" issues that \"Charles would rather impale himself on a rusty sword than meet up with someone who has wrought such vengeful misery on the royal family for so many years now.\"\n\nThe New York Post also reported that \"negotiations\" for a meeting between Harry and his father this week broke down over certain unnamed \"demands\" by the duke, possibly over who could be in the room with them. \"Although on the surface it looks like a snub, Harry made it very difficult for his father,\" royal commentator Charlotte Griffiths said on GB News.\n\nBut before Harry traveled to London from his home in Montecito, he had made no secret of his desire to see his father again, as the king undergoes treatment for an undisclosed form cancer, The Telegraph reported. In February, Harry told ABC News how he jumped on a plane, \"as soon as I could,\" to fly to London to see his father, after his father publicly disclosed that he had cancer.\n\n\"Look, I love my family,\" Harry insisted. \"The fact that I was able to get on a plane and go and see him and spend any time with him, I'm grateful for that.\"\n\nBefore this week, royal observers thought that Harry might use his time in London to spend some time with Charles, marking another step towards a reconciliation.\n\nHarry has been on the outs from his family ever since he and Meghan, his American wife, stepped away from royal duties in 2020 and moved to her home state of California. The estrangement grew as Harry and Meghan, via interviews, a Netflix series and Harry's memoir \"Spare,\" publicly criticized the monarchy and alleged that certain family members were cruel, guilty of racism -- or of \"unconscious bias\" as Harry preferred to put it. Harry also accused family members, particularly his father's wife, Queen Camilla, of leaking negative news about them to favorite tabloid journalists.\n\nBut Harry has since tried to convey the message that he hopes to heal the rift with his family and move past their differences -- especially after learning that both his father and Kate Middleton, the wife of his brother, Prince William, have been diagnosed with cancer.\n\nIn his interview with ABC News, Harry spoke about how an illness like cancer can bring families together. He also vowed to visit his father in the near future. \"I've got other trips planned that would take me through the UK or back to the UK, so I'll stop in and see my family as much as I can,\" he said.\n\nStill, as much as Harry tried to portray his \"dash\" to London in February as a positive step towards reconciliation, The Telegraph noted that his trip still faced challenges. Harry's sudden arrival in London reportedly forced Charles to change his plans at the last minute, and Harry wasn't invited to travel to his country estate with his father as he had hoped.\n\nWriting in the Daily Mail, Kay suggested that Charles' cancer diagnosis may have had the opposite effect on his relationship with his son. \"The illness has, if anything, added to their estrangement,\" Kay said.\n\nThe snub narrative has been amplified this week by the announcement that Charles would officially hand over a key ceremonial role in the British military to William, the Prince of Wales and his direct heir. The king will name William as colonel-in-chief of the Army Air Corps.\n\nThe Telegraph reported that Charles probably would have handed the colonelcy to Harry, an Army veteran who had flown Apache helicopters in Afghanistan. But the late Queen Elizabeth II removed Harry's military titles when he stepped away from royal duties.\n\nAt this point, the king may find that encounters with Harry have become more of \"a burden than a a pleasure,\" especially as he battles cancer, Kay wrote. Two people important to him also may have a problem with welcoming Harry back into the royal fold. These two people are Camilla, who has been the subject of Harry's \"lacerating attacks,\" and William, Kay added. Harry has portrayed William as having anger management issues, while William may never forgive his brother for hurtful comments he made in \"Spare\" about Kate.\n\n\"The opposition of Camilla and William would be formidable to Charles,\" Kay quoted a courtier as saying. \"For all his affection for Harry -- which remains -- and sadness at the deep rift that has developed, his ties with his wife and older son are far deeper.\"", "source": {"uri": "sentinelandenterprise.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sentinel and Enterprise"}, "authors": [{"uri": "martha_ross@sentinelandenterprise.com", After the event, Harry met with fans outside as they shouted: \"We love you Harry\". Hundreds of people lined the street to try and catch a glimpse of the Duke.\n\nHarry, whose main home is now in the US with Meghan Markle and their children, will jet out of Britain in preparation for his trip to Nigeria with his wife.\n\nOn Thursday, his brother William was seen smiling as he smiled as he visited sunny Cornwall for two royal engagements in Newquay and the Isles of Scilly. He began his visit in Newquay at a housing project which will provide 24 homes with wraparound support for homeless people.\n\nQueen Camilla meanwhile met with former TV newsreader Angela Rippon at Buckingham Palace to mark the 90th anniversary of Brooke, a charity dedicated to improving the lives of working horses, donkeys, and mules.\n\nYesterday, she and King Charles seemed in good spirits as they hosted guests at Buckingham Palace garden party. They said: \"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme. Shortly after touching down in London, it was revealed that King Charles was too busy to meet with his son, despite weeks of speculation that they could be meeting.\n\nAnd then, just mere hours after it was confirmed that King Charles would not be meeting with Prince Harry, Buckingham Palace announced that the King would hand the Prince of Wales a military honour long thought to be destined for the Duke of Sussex. Prince William is now colonel-in-chief of the Army Air Corp - the regiment Prince Harry served with in Afghanistan.\n\nRoyal expert and author Tom Quinn exclusively told The Mirror: \"King Charles' announcement that Prince Harry is being stripped of his role as Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps is a real kick in the teeth for the son who always felt marginalised and underrated.\n\n\"What makes it much worse is that the role is being given to the very man who Harry sees as the cause of so many of his problems - his brother. And the announcement was deliberately made during Harry's brief visit to the UK to have maximum impact - it shows Harry that he really is no longer welcome.\"\n\nPrince Harry 'in tears' when King Other commitments come first for the monarch, leaving Harry at the 'bottom of the list'.\n\nIt was also confirmed on Tuesday that Charles has given Prince William the role of Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps - Harry's old regiment.\n\nAccording to royal historian and expert Tessa Dunlop, Harry will be keenly aware of his position as he steps inside St Paul's - also the site of Charles and Diana's ill-fated wedding.\n\n\"Today, every step of the way, he will shadow box his former life, trapped in the web of monarchy that is apparently impossible to escape, only now he is outside the institution, looking in,\" Tessa told The Mirror.\n\nShe continued: \"The King doesn't have time to fit the Duke of Sussex into his schedule. But if not redemption now, then when?\"\n\nThe last time Harry met with his father in person was in February when the Prince briefly returned to London following the King's cancer diagnosis,\n\n\"It was a glimmer of hope for a more amicable future and many presumed a further meeting would be forthcoming in the wake of today's Invictus Games anniversary celebration,\" according to Tessa.\n\n\"Instead the Duke will give a reading in St Paul's Cathedral, the epic venue of his parents' fated wedding, with no significant members of the royal family by his side. just three miles away from his father who attended first Buckingham Palace garden party of the year.\n\nRoyal expert Robert Jobson spoke to The Sun exclusively about the royal pair not meeting.\n\n\"People think if Harry rolls into town there's going to be some sort of reconciliation,\" he said.\n\n\"But you're going to realize there's been a lot of water under the bridge, a lot of portrayal of trust.\n\n\"That takes time to rebuild, to rebuild, and I don't think we're anywhere near the stage of rebuilding trust.\"\n\nHe added: \"Harry effectively took it by himself to come see his dad when he said that he that he had been diagnosed with cancer that would be seen by as many as a good thing.\n\n\"But at the time I think the King didn't want all the media circus that would accompany Harry's arrival.\"\n\nMeanwhile, royal author Ingrid Seward claimed Charles \"snubbed\" Harry as he feared he'd be used as a PR tool to boost his son's image.\n\nShe explained: \"He's the father of Harry. It would look nice if they met.\n\n\"He probably he doesn't want it to be used as a PR opportunity.\n\n\"Or maybe Harry's being the one being difficult and we we just don't know.\"\n\nAnd, in another snub, the King also revealed Prince William would next week be taking charge of Harry's former helicopter regiment.\n\nThe Monarch said his eldest son will be honoured as the Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps.\n\nThe event will take place in front of an Apache -- the type of helicopter Harry flew when serving in Afghanistan.\n\nRoyal expert Richard Fitzwilliams told The Sun: \"This timing is deliberate.\n\n\"It's to send a deliberate message to Harry that the Royal Family has not forgotten what has been happening over the last four years.\"\n\nHowever, the duke was backed by Princess Shortly after touching down in London, it was revealed that King Charles was too busy to meet with his son, despite weeks of speculation that they could be meeting.\n\nAnd then, just mere hours after it was confirmed that King Charles would not be meeting with Prince Harry, Buckingham Palace announced that the King would hand the Prince of Wales a military honour long thought to be destined for the Duke of Sussex. Prince William is now colonel-in-chief of the Army Air Corp - the regiment Prince Harry served with in Afghanistan.\n\nFor all the latest on news, politics, sports, and showbiz from the USA, go to The Mirror US.\n\nREAD MORE: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle to have bombshells exposed in upcoming German documentary\n\nPrince Harry is back in the UK for a short trip from the States\n\nRoyal expert and author Tom Quinn exclusively told The Mirror: \"King Charles' announcement that Prince Harry is being stripped of his role as Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps is a real kick in the teeth for the son who always felt marginalised and underrated. What makes it much worse is that the role is being given to the very man who Harry sees as the cause of so many of his problems - his brother. And the announcement was deliberately made during Harry's brief visit to the UK to have maximum impact - it shows Harry that he really is no longer welcome.\"\n\nMr Quinn claimed that the senior royals \"knew\" that the announcement would \"really hurt\" Harry, before revealing that \"he is said to have been in tears when he heard\". He added: \"But they have decided the gloves are off and that Harry needs to realise that when you betray the family, you don't just escape the things you hated doing as a working royal. You also lose the things you loved.\"\n\n\"Being Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps was something Harry really did enjoy and of which he was very proud,\" Mr Quinn went on. \"There is a rushed feel to the whole thing too as if they can't wait to be rid of this troublesome prince - which is why Harry's role will be transferred to William in just a few days' time, on 13 May.\n\n\"Harry feels his time in the military was a rare happy time in his life when he was judged on his merits as a man not on his merits as a member of the Royal Family.\"\n\nConcluding his thoughts on the situation, Mr Quinn added: \"Having always hated being the spare in terms of the succession he now finds that one of the few important roles he had as the younger brother has now been handed over to the person Harry himself described as his nemesis. He hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nDuring a chat with The Mirror, royal author Tom Quinn has claimed that the King made a rather cheeky joke when he learned that Harry wanted to see him during his brief UK visit.\n\n\"When King Charles heard his son was planning to return for the Invictus Games, he joked that if he saw Harry he would have to have him searched first to see if he was taping their conversation!\" Quinn said.\n\n\"And, of course, at many levels this is no joking matter,\" he then added.\n\nQuinn then went on to claim that the King has been left relieved that Harry won't be releasing a second memoir.\n\n\"There was a sigh of relief at Kensington Palace and Clarence House that Harry appears to have scrapped the idea of a second book after his best-seller Spare, but the focus has now switched to Meghan. {"uri": "8117761922", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:46:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:46:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:45:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/why-royal-family-did-not-163516095.html", "title": "Why the Royal Family Did Not Attend Prince Harry's Invictus Games Service in London", "body": "The Duke of Sussex is in the U.K. for an Invictus Games-focused trip\n\nPrince Harry's service in London to mark the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games did not bring together members of the royal family.\n\nAs the Duke of Sussex, 39, attended a Service of Thanksgiving at St. Paul's Cathedral on May 8, family members including King Charles, Prince William and Kate Middleton were not in attendance.\n\nPrince Harry traveled to the U.K. from his California home to mark the 10th anniversary of the international adaptive sports tournament for wounded, injured and sick service personnel and veterans, which he founded in 2014.\n\nEarlier this week, it was disclosed that Harry wouldn't be able to meet with his father King Charles during his time in the U.K. due to the monarch's \"full\" schedule -- which includes the palace garden party hosted by the King at the same time, just a few miles away at Buckingham Palace. Along with Charles and Queen Camilla, the garden party was also attended by royal family members Princess Anne, Prince Edward and his wife Sophie, Duchess of Edinburgh and the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester.\n\n\"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not The Duke will meet with his father while in the U.K. this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full program. The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon,\" a spokesperson for the Duke of Sussex said on May 7.\n\nRelated: Meghan Markle Won't Join Prince Harry in the U.K. Next Month Before Heading to Nigeria Together\n\nThe Duke of Sussex also traveled to the U.K. in February to privately visit his father the King after Buckingham Palace announced the monarch's cancer diagnosis. King Charles postponed public-facing duties and continued to work behind the scenes after he started receiving treatment, which the palace said coincided with its Feb. 5 announcement about his health. King Charles resumed forward-facing duties on April 30, and Queen Camilla later said she thought her husband was \"really thrilled to be out.\"\n\nPrince Harry's February trip to the U.K. did not involve meeting with his brother, Prince William, or his sister-in-law, Princess Kate. A royal source said at the time there were \"no plans\" for the brothers to get together.\n\nIn March, the Princess of Wales, 42, announced that she was undergoing treatment for cancer following abdominal surgery in January. PEOPLE understands that Prince Harry and Meghan Markle privately reached out to the Prince and Princess of Wales amid Kate's diagnosis.\n\nThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex also shared their support by releasing a statement after Princess Kate announced the news about her health.\n\n\"We wish health and healing for Kate and the family, and hope they are able to do so privately and in peace,\" the Duke and Duchess of Sussex said in a statement shared with PEOPLE on March 22, the day of Princess Kate's announcement.\n\nRelated: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry to Visit Nigeria in May for a Special Reason\n\nBefore the Princess of Wales announced that she had cancer, a family source told PEOPLE that Prince Harry and Meghan were in the dark about her abdominal surgery and recovery.\n\n\"They are aware of everything that goes on back in England, but are being left out of any details regarding Kate,\" the source told PEOPLE. \"There is clearly no trust.\"\n\nThe itinerary for Prince Harry's Invictus-focused trip also included a panel discussion, and the Duke of Sussex delivered a reading at St. Paul's Cathedral during the Service of Thanksgiving.\n\nHomeland actor Damian Lewis recited the poem \"Invictus,\" which inspired the competition's motto, and the ceremony was attended by representatives from across the participating nations of the Invictus Games, including members of the wounded, injured and sick service personnel and veteran community. Community members, supporters and beneficiaries also gave readings in the service led by The Very Reverend Andrew Tremlett, Dean of St. Paul's.\n\nCan't get enough of PEOPLE's Royals coverage? Sign up for our free Royals newsletter to get the latest updates on Kate Middleton, Meghan Markle and more!\n\nPrince Harry's latest U.K. trip was announced on April 28, and he made the journey without his wife Meghan, 42, though they are soon due to reunite. PEOPLE confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex will travel to Nigeria later this week upon the invitation on behalf of the Chief of Defense Staff, the country's highest-ranking military official.\n\nDuring their visit, Prince Harry and Meghan will meet with service members and participate in a variety of cultural activities in a visit highlighting the Invictus Games. Nigeria made its event debut at the sixth cycle of the adaptive sports tournament in D\u00fcsseldorf, Germany in September 2023, and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex spent time with the team and fans in the stands.\n\nPrince Harry joked that his wife was rooting for the squad at the opening ceremony after discovering that she has Nigerian heritage, a revelation made on her Archetypes podcast in 2022. Nigerian Minister of Defense Alhaji Mohammed Abubakar Badaru also attended the competition in Germany, and has expressed interest in hosting the Invictus Games in the future, should the country be granted the opportunity.\n\nWhile plans are in motion for the next Invictus Games in Vancouver and Whistler, Canada, in February 2025, the eighth iteration of the Invictus Games might take it back to the United States. On May 1, the Invictus Games Foundation revealed the shortlist of cities hoping to host the 2027 Invictus Games, with just two contenders: Washington, D.C. and Birmingham, U.K.\n\nThe 2027 cycle will be the eighth Invictus Games, following the competitions in London (2014), Orlando (2016), Toronto (2017), Sydney (2018), The Hague (2022, bumped from 2020 due to the pandemic) and D\u00fcsseldorf in The event marked 10 years since the inception of the games, which are a Paralympic-style event for wounded service people and veterans.\n\nThe service was attended by two siblings of the late Princess of Wales: Charles Spencer and Lady Jane Fellowes.\n\nThe duke was also joined by actor Damian Lewis, who read the poem \"Invictus.\" Harry once named Lewis as the actor he'd want to portray him in the Netflix series The Crown.\n\nKing Charles and Prince William both had other engagements on Harry's big day.\n\nThe monarch and Queen Camilla held a garden party at Buckingham Palace, which was attended by members of the royal family including Princess Anne, Prince Edward and Sophie, the Duchess of Edinburgh.\n\nThe Prince of Wales was also previously engaged, as he conducted an investiture ceremony at Windsor Castle earlier in the day.\n\nA spokesperson for the Duke of Sussex confirmed to HuffPost on Tuesday that the prince would not be able to meet with Charles while he was in the UK.\n\n\"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not The Duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme,\" a spokesperson for Harry said in a statement shared with HuffPost.\n\nThe spokesperson added that \"The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nWhile Meghan Markle did not accompany Harry for his brief trip to the UK, she will join him later this month for a trip to Nigeria.", {"uri": "8118033960", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "20:37:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T20:37:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T20:36:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/royal-family/2024/05/08/king-and-prince-harry-gulf-obvious-three-miles-apart/", "title": "The King and Prince Harry were less than three miles apart but the gulf has never been more obvious", "body": "As the King delighted in meeting the guests at a Buckingham Palace garden party Prince Harry was supported by his maternal family\n\nAt Buckingham Palace, the King stepped out in front of 8,000 guests at his first garden party since his cancer diagnosis. Across town shortly afterwards, the Duke of Sussex took his place at St Paul's Cathedral for a service celebrating 10 years of the Invictus Games.\n\nFather and son were less than three miles away from one another, but have never seemed further apart.\n\nAt the side of the King was a Royal family out in force: the Queen, the Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh, the Princess Royal and the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester all taking their place for the national anthem.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex arrived at his event alone.\n\nHowever, inside St Paul's Prince Harry had a team of his own in the shape of his maternal family. His uncle and aunt, Earl Spencer and Lady Jane Fellowes, there in support, greeted with emotional hugs.\n\nThey were joined by Mark Dyer, a former Army officer often described as a \"father figure\", Jamie Lowther-Pinkerton, a former private secretary to both Prince William and Prince Harry, and - in a sign of the times - David Sherborne, the Duke's barrister.\n\nOutside St Paul's, a crowd waited for a Prince Harry walkabout, taking selfies and clasping his hand as he made his way along.\n\nThe Prince of Wales did not attend either event, spending the morning holding a Windsor Castle investiture before returning home to his own family.\n\nThe separate outings show the state of the Royal family as it stands: Team Windsor on duty and an emerging Team Sussex elsewhere.\n\nIt was all a long way from scenes a decade ago, when Princes Charles, William and Harry celebrated the first Invictus Games in London with public appearances that saw them laughing, kissing on the cheek and sharing a joke looking at a phone screen.\n\nAt the 10th anniversary service on Wednesday, Prince Harry read 1 Corinthians 12: 4-11, to speak of \"service\" and the \"common good\".\n\nThe dean, the Very Rev Andrew Tremlett, gave a welcome hailing the tremendous achievements of the sick and injured military personnel from 23 nations who compete in the Games. Actor Damian Lewis, 53, recited the Invictus poem by William Henley.\n\nPrince Harry, who beamed and waved as he entered St Paul's, later joined Invictus competitors and staff for a reception in the cathedral's crypt. He spent the rest of the day in meetings with his remaining UK patronages.\n\nAt Buckingham Palace, in overlapping events, the King led the Royal family in the annual celebration of community service, his first garden party since his cancer diagnosis.\n\nAs he stood on the terrace with the Queen he heard a loud cheer at the end of the national anthem and waved his black top hat to acknowledge the crowd with thanks.\n\nWalking across the lawn, he shook hand after hand and answered the questions about his health repeatedly.\n\nOne guest told him he was \"looking so much better\". The King replied: \"I'm not doing badly.\"\n\n\"How are you feeling, Sir?\" one man asked, with the King saying \"Not too bad\" in response.\n\nThe King, wearing sunscreen in the heat, occasionally dabbed his nose with a handkerchief, but was described by an onlooker as seeming in excellent spirits, peppering guests with questions about where they had come from and what they did.\n\nIt is his next step towards resuming a regular programme of public activity, even as he continues his cancer treatment.\n\nAs such, the garden party, just like the Invictus service, should have been celebratory. Instead, the day was overshadowed somewhat by the rumbling question of the King and his younger son meeting. In the end, sources said, they did not.\n\nThe Duke had hoped for a meeting with his father before his trip to Britain, it is said, though recollections seem to vary once again as to whether a formal, timely request was made.\n\nEventually, as he landed on Tuesday morning, Harry's spokeswoman issued a written statement confirming that the King would be too busy to see his younger son. \"The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon,\" she said.\n\nA spokesman for the King said nothing.\n\nThose within the palace have privately raised the issue of trust, pointing to a King who has a lot on his plate.\n\nThe last time Prince Harry visited, for a 30-minute meeting shortly after the King was diagnosed with cancer, it was swiftly followed by an interview on US breakfast television.\n\nAt the time his actual words were received calmly back in Britain, but that he was open to being asked about it on Good Morning America did nothing to restore trust for future visits.\n\nThis week, within days, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex will arrive in Nigeria for a tour with all the attendant press and publicity that entails.\n\nThey are there in part to promote Invictus, in a country the Duchess has recently claimed a personal link to. She is, she said in a 2022 podcast, 43 per cent Nigerian according to a genealogy test.\n\nThe King, who is Head of Commonwealth but has not been able to travel overseas in 2024, will be kept informed of their activities.\n\nPerhaps on a different visit to the UK, when the Duke is not about to fly immediately into a high-profile, headline-grabbing Commonwealth tour, there will be time for father and son to talk quietly.\n\nThe palace way is formal\n\nThose who know Prince Harry say he simply wants to see his father.\n\nThe explanation of being \"too busy\", volunteered by the Sussexes rather than the palace, has inevitably raised eyebrows. The King is busy, there is no doubting that, particularly as he navigates his return to public duty. The palace way of arranging meetings is formal, the lines of communication with the Sussexes limited. But where there's a will there's a way.\n\nIn February 2024, after his last visit to Britain, when asked whether it was possible that his father's illness would have a \"galvanising and sort of reunifying effect\" for his family, Prince Harry said: \"I'm sure.\"\n\nThree months on, another flying visit under his belt, and that dream is no closer to reality.\n\nThe gulf between Prince Harry and the King, in communication and expectation, seems no closer to being bridged.\n\nIt was not so long ago that another father and son had their differences aired; a young Prince Charles cast in the public imagination as the overly emotional son with a father who did not understand him.\n\n\"He's a romantic and I'm a pragmatist,\" Prince Philip once said of his eldest. \"That means we do see things differently.\"\n\nNo one would call the current King \"unfeeling\", as was said of his own late father. But perhaps, in all of this upset, he has found his inner pragmatist too.", "source": {"uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Telegraph"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8117989615", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "19:55:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T19:55:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T19:55:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.mercurynews.com/2024/05/08/it-looks-like-king-charles-is-done-with-harry-palace-gates-firmly-closed/", "title": "It looks like King Charles is done with Harry: 'Palace gates firmly closed'", "body": "Royal watchers opined that Harry was 'snubbed' and that the king was sending an 'ominous' message by failing to schedule time to see him when he's in London\n\nPrince Harry's team subtly but surely conveyed the hurt he feels that his father, King Charles III, wouldn't make time to see him when he was in London this week for a 10th anniversary celebration of the Invictus Games.\n\nSure, there was talk from Harry's spokesperson about the two men having \"scheduling\" conflicts during the Duke of Sussex's three-day trip to London. Arriving from California Tuesday, Harry had some meetings, then arrived at St. Paul's Cathedral Wednesday for the Invictus Games anniversary.\n\nMeanwhile on Wednesday, Charles hosted a garden party at Buckingham Palace, then was scheduled to have an audience with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and a Privy Council meeting. He's also had hospital appointments for his ongoing treatment for cancer.\n\nIn a statement, Harry's spokesperson said that a meeting between the two was \"unfortunately ... not possible due to His Majesty's full program,\" The Telegraph reported. The spokesman also said that Harry is \"understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nWhether Harry really is \"understanding\" may never be known -- until anonymous \"insider\" sources from either his camp or from Buckingham Palace leak behind-the-scenes observations to the media. But royal watchers definitely opined Wednesday that Harry was \"snubbed\" and that his father was sending him an \"ominous\" message.\n\nCharles' unwillingness to schedule even 15 minutes to see his estranged son this week, after Harry traveled all the way from California, is an indication that \"the palace gates remain firmly closed,\" said journalist and author Richard Kay. The relationship between Harry and with his father and the rest of the royal family appears to be \"more broken than ever,\" Kay also said.\n\nRoyal expert Michael Cole agreed, telling the Daily Mail: \"It is quite a snub. For the king to not see his younger son, although the two men will be only two miles apart (Wednesday), gives an indication of the depth of the divide.\"\n\n\"The prodigal son is not welcome -- not for the present, anyway,\" Cole continued. \"In royal terms, this is big medicine. Prince Harry is bound to see it for what it is, the clearest possible indication of the hurt that has been caused.\"\n\nPiers Morgan, a fierce critic of Harry and his wife, Meghan Markle, was even more blunt about \"the snub,\" writing in The Sun: \"Let's be honest: if Charles had really wanted to see him, he'd have made the time. That's the whole point of being a king, you get to do what the hell you like.\"\n\nBut Morgan said it's clear from the statements about \"scheduling\" issues that \"Charles would rather impale himself on a rusty sword than meet up with someone who has wrought such vengeful misery on the royal family for so many years now.\"\n\nBefore Harry traveled to London from his home in Montecito, he had made no secret of his desire to see his father again, as the king undergoes treatment for an undisclosed form cancer, The Telegraph reported. In February, Harry told ABC News how he jumped on a plane, \"as soon as I could,\" to fly to London to see his father, after his father publicly disclosed that he had cancer.\n\n\"Look, I love my family,\" Harry insisted. \"The fact that I was able to get on a plane and go and see him and spend any time with him, I'm grateful for that.\"\n\nBefore this week, royal observers thought that Harry might use his time in London to spend some time with Charles, marking another step towards a reconciliation.\n\nHarry has been on the outs from his family ever since he and Meghan, his American wife, stepped away from royal duties in 2020 and moved to her home state of California. The estrangement grew as Harry and Meghan, via interviews, a Netflix series and Harry's memoir \"Spare,\" publicly criticized the monarchy and alleged that certain family members were cruel, guilty of racism -- or of \"unconscious bias\" as Harry preferred to put it. Harry also accused family members, particularly his father's wife, Queen Camilla, of leaking negative news about them to favorite tabloid journalists.\n\nBut Harry has since tried to convey the message that he hopes to heal the rift with his family and move past their differences -- especially after learning that both his father and Kate Middleton, the wife of his brother, Prince William, have been diagnosed with cancer.\n\nIn his interview with ABC News, Harry spoke about how an illness like cancer can bring families together. He also vowed to visit his father in the near future. \"I've got other trips planned that would take me through the UK or back to the UK, so I'll stop in and see my family as much as I can,\" he said.\n\nStill, as much as Harry tried to portray his \"dash\" to London in February as a positive step towards reconciliation, The Telegraph noted that his trip still faced challenges. Harry's sudden arrival in London reportedly forced Charles to change his plans at the last minute, and Harry wasn't invited to travel with his father to his country estate.\n\nWriting in the Daily Mail, Kay suggested that Charles' cancer diagnosis may have had the opposite effect on his relationship with his son. \"The illness has, if anything, added to their estrangement,\" Kay said.\n\nThe snub narrative has been amplified this week by the announcement that Charles would officially hand over a key ceremonial role in the British military to William, the Prince of Wales and his direct heir. The king will name William as colonel-in-chief of the Army Air Corps.\n\nThe Telegraph reported that Charles probably would have handed the colonelcy to Harry, an Army veteran who had flown Apache helicopters in Afghanistan. But the late Queen Elizabeth II removed Harry's military titles when he stepped away from royal duties.\n\nAt this point, the king may find that encounters with Harry have become more of \"a burden than a a pleasure,\" especially as he battles cancer, Kay wrote. Two people important to him also may have a problem with welcoming Harry back into the royal fold. These two people are Camilla, who has been the subject of Harry's \"lacerating attacks,\" and William, Kay added. Harry has portrayed William as having anger management issues, while William may never forgive his brother for hurtful comments he made in \"Spare\" about Kate.\n\n\"The opposition of Camilla and William would be formidable to Charles,\" Kay quoted a courtier as saying. \"For all his affection for Harry -- which remains -- and sadness at the deep rift that has developed, his ties with his wife and older son are far deeper.\"", "source": {"uri": "mercurynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "San Jose Mercury News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "martha_ross@mercurynews.com", "name": "Martha Ross", {"uri": "8117990007", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "19:56:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T19:56:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T19:56:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.eastbaytimes.com/2024/05/08/it-looks-like-king-charles-is-done-with-harry-palace-gates-firmly-closed/", "title": "It looks like King Charles is done with Harry: 'Palace gates firmly closed'", "body": "Prince Harry's team subtly but surely conveyed the hurt he feels that his father, King Charles III, wouldn't make time to see him when he was in London this week for a 10th anniversary celebration of the Invictus Games.\n\nSure, there was talk from Harry's spokesperson about the two men having \"scheduling\" conflicts during the Duke of Sussex's three-day trip to London. Arriving from California Tuesday, Harry had some meetings, then arrived at St. Paul's Cathedral Wednesday for the Invictus Games anniversary.\n\nMeanwhile on Wednesday, Charles hosted a garden party at Buckingham Palace, then was scheduled to have an audience with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and a Privy Council meeting. He's also had hospital appointments for his ongoing treatment for cancer.\n\nIn a statement, Harry's spokesperson said that a meeting between the two was \"unfortunately ... not possible due to His Majesty's full program,\" The Telegraph reported. The spokesman also said that Harry is \"understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nWhether Harry really is \"understanding\" may never be known -- until anonymous \"insider\" sources from either his camp or from Buckingham Palace leak behind-the-scenes observations to the media. But royal watchers definitely opined Wednesday that Harry was \"snubbed\" and that his father was sending him an \"ominous\" message.\n\nCharles' unwillingness to schedule even 15 minutes to see his estranged son this week, after Harry traveled all the way from California, is an indication that \"the palace gates remain firmly closed,\" said journalist and author Richard Kay. The relationship between Harry and with his father and the rest of the royal family appears to be \"more broken than ever,\" Kay also said.\n\nRoyal expert Michael Cole agreed, telling the Daily Mail: \"It is quite a snub. For the king to not see his younger son, although the two men will be only two miles apart (Wednesday), gives an indication of the depth of the divide.\"\n\n\"The prodigal son is not welcome -- not for the present, anyway,\" Cole continued. \"In royal terms, this is big medicine. Prince Harry is bound to see it for what it is, the clearest possible indication of the hurt that has been caused.\"\n\nPiers Morgan, a fierce critic of Harry and his wife, Meghan Markle, was even more blunt about \"the snub,\" writing in The Sun: \"Let's be honest: if Charles had really wanted to see him, he'd have made the time. That's the whole point of being a king, you get to do what the hell you like.\"\n\nBut Morgan said it's clear from the statements about \"scheduling\" issues that \"Charles would rather impale himself on a rusty sword than meet up with someone who has wrought such vengeful misery on the royal family for so many years now.\"\n\nBefore Harry traveled to London from his home in Montecito, he had made no secret of his desire to see his father again, as the king undergoes treatment for an undisclosed form cancer, The Telegraph reported. In February, Harry told ABC News how he jumped on a plane, \"as soon as I could,\" to fly to London to see his father, after his father publicly disclosed that he had cancer.\n\n\"Look, I love my family,\" Harry insisted. \"The fact that I was able to get on a plane and go and see him and spend any time with him, I'm grateful for that.\"\n\nBefore this week, royal observers thought that Harry might use his time in London to spend some time with Charles, marking another step towards a reconciliation.\n\nHarry has been on the outs from his family ever since he and Meghan, his American wife, stepped away from royal duties in 2020 and moved to her home state of California. The estrangement grew as Harry and Meghan, via interviews, a Netflix series and Harry's memoir \"Spare,\" publicly criticized the monarchy and alleged that certain family members were cruel, guilty of racism -- or of \"unconscious bias\" as Harry preferred to put it. Harry also accused family members, particularly his father's wife, Queen Camilla, of leaking negative news about them to favorite tabloid journalists.\n\nBut Harry has since tried to convey the message that he hopes to heal the rift with his family and move past their differences -- especially after learning that both his father and Kate Middleton, the wife of his brother, Prince William, have been diagnosed with cancer.\n\nIn his interview with ABC News, Harry spoke about how an illness like cancer can bring families together. He also vowed to visit his father in the near future. \"I've got other trips planned that would take me through the UK or back to the UK, so I'll stop in and see my family as much as I can,\" he said.\n\nStill, as much as Harry tried to portray his \"dash\" to London in February as a positive step towards reconciliation, The Telegraph noted that his trip still faced challenges. Harry's sudden arrival in London reportedly forced Charles to change his plans at the last minute, and Harry wasn't invited to travel with his father to his country estate.\n\nWriting in the Daily Mail, Kay suggested that Charles' cancer diagnosis may have had the opposite effect on his relationship with his son. \"The illness has, if anything, added to their estrangement,\" Kay said.\n\nThe snub narrative has been amplified this week by the announcement that Charles would officially hand over a key ceremonial role in the British military to William, the Prince of Wales and his direct heir. The king will name William as colonel-in-chief of the Army Air Corps.\n\nThe Telegraph reported that Charles probably would have handed the colonelcy to Harry, an Army veteran who had flown Apache helicopters in Afghanistan. But the late Queen Elizabeth II removed Harry's military titles when he stepped away from royal duties.\n\nAt this point, the king may find that encounters with Harry have become more of \"a burden than a a pleasure,\" especially as he battles cancer, Kay wrote. Two people important to him also may have a problem with welcoming Harry back into the royal fold. These two people are Camilla, who has been the subject of Harry's \"lacerating attacks,\" and William, Kay added. Harry has portrayed William as having anger management issues, while William may never forgive his brother for hurtful comments he made in \"Spare\" about Kate.\n\n\"The opposition of Camilla and William would be formidable to Charles,\" Kay quoted a courtier as saying. \"For all his affection for Harry -- which remains -- and sadness at the deep rift that has developed, his ties with his wife and older son are far deeper.\"", "source": {"uri": "eastbaytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "East Bay Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "martha_ross@eastbaytimes.com", "name": "Martha Ross", {"uri": "2024-05-350131621", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:09:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:09:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:00:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/king-charles-gives-prince-harry-080045520.html", "title": "King Charles gives Prince Harry 'slap in the face' with announcement after refusing to see his son: expert", "body": "Just after learning that he would not be able to see his father due to the king's busy schedule, Buckingham Palace announced on Wednesday that Harry's brother, Prince William, will be made colonel in chief of the Army Air Corps. The Prince of Wales is succeeding King Charles III as head of the regiment.\n\nThe U.K.'s Independent noted that it's likely the honor would have been given to Harry, if he hadn't stepped down as a senior member of the royal family, because he served with the unit in Afghanistan. A spokesperson for Buckingham Palace didn't immediately respond to Fox News Digital's request for comment.\n\nPRINCE HARRY 'HIT HARD' BY KATE MIDDLETON CANCER BATTLE, BUT PRINCE WILLIAM WON'T LET HIM 'NEAR' WIFE: EXPERT\n\n\"It is one slap in the face after another for Harry,\" royal expert Ian Pelham Turner told Fox News Digital about the announcement, which some U.K. outlets have described as another \"snub\" for the prince.\n\n\"I think this is a mistake,\" said Pelham Turner about the king not choosing to meet with his son ahead of the bombshell news. \"Patronizing reasons like Harry might spill the beans on a conversation in any future book ... are not justified and will only add petrol to the flames. Charles ... [was] touchy feeling, holding hands with cancer victims but cannot stretch out to his son.\"\n\nREAD ON THE FOX NEWS APP\n\n\"Taking away another military regiment ... means nothing to the British public,\" Pelham Turner said. \"But it does to Harry. [It's] the regiment he served in until 2014. Giving it to William will only further highlight the churlish divisions and not show a forgiving nature. ... On a day when Harry is at an event to celebrate the Invictus Games ... I wonder what the recipients ... think of the betrayal.\"\n\nHarry, 39, arrived in London without his wife, Meghan Markle, by his side. The prince joined a panel on Tuesday for the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games. The discussion, \"The IGF Conversation: Realizing a Global Community,\" aimed to highlight service personnel and their families.\n\nThen on Wednesday, the Duke of Sussex appeared at St. Paul's Cathedral for a service commemorating the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games.\n\nOn that same day, Charles and his wife, Queen Camilla, welcomed thousands of guests to Buckingham Palace for the first garden party of 2024. The festivities are a longstanding tradition that dates to the 1860s. Other members of the royal family, including Princess Anne, Prince Edward, Sophie, the Duchess of Edinburgh, and the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester, were in attendance.\n\nCLICK HERE TO SIGN UP FOR THE ENTERTAINMENT NEWSLETTER\n\nA spokesperson for the Duke of Sussex previously confirmed to Fox News Digital that the prince wouldn't be meeting with his father.\n\n\"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not The Duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it, unfortunately, will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme,\" the statement said.\n\n\"The Duke, of course, is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nHarry's sister-in-law, Princess Kate Middleton, has been keeping a low profile as she seeks treatment for cancer. The king, 75, who was also diagnosed with cancer, has returned to public-facing duties as he continues his recovery.\n\nChristopher Andersen, author of \"The King,\" told Fox News Digital that the king and the Prince of Wales, 41, sent a clear message to Harry.\n\n\"If there were any doubts that Harry is dead to his father and brother, then this one-two punch from King Charles should dispel them once and for all,\" Andersen said. \"By announcing that he was too busy to see Harry, even though the two men are just two miles apart, and then officially giving Harry's colonel in chief of the Army Air Corps title to William - one of the honorary military titles Harry cherished most - the king is slamming the door in Harry's face.\"\n\n\"This was a calculated, even cruel snub,\" Andersen said. \"Under other circumstances, I would have chalked it up to the fatal tone-deafness that the palace is so famous for. But the king could easily have carved out time to see Harry, and the announcement giving Harry's old title to William didn't have to happen just as Harry arrived in London. This was all very deliberate and very petty - and very personal.\"\n\nAndersen said Harry has \"put up a good front\" as he remained dedicated to highlighting his passion project.\n\n\"Having to put up with so much emotional turmoil throughout his entire life, he has learned to compartmentalize,\" Andersen said. \"He certainly gave no indication that anything was wrong during the Invictus ceremonies. That doesn't mean that Harry isn't frustrated and, frankly, deeply wounded by the royals' continued intransigence.\"\n\n\"It's also very sad that the king and other senior royals have made no effort to embrace the Invictus Games,\" Andersen continued. \"Queen Elizabeth was a huge booster of Invictus and, in 2016, even did a memorable TV commercial for the games with Harry and Barack and Michelle Obama.\n\n\"You would think otherwise, given the king's health problems, not to mention Princess Kate's. This would be the perfect time for Charles to seize the olive branch being extended repeatedly by Harry. But the king and Prince William are not in a forgiving mood.\"\n\nHarry has had a troubled relationship with the royal family since he quit royal duties. According to the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, the unbearable intrusions and racist attitudes of the British media prompted the move to California in 2020.\n\nLIKE WHAT YOU'RE READING? CLICK HERE FOR MORE ENTERTAINMENT NEWS\n\nAfter their departure, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex aired their grievances about life as royals. In 2021, they sat down with Oprah Winfrey for an interview that was viewed by 50 million people globally. Following the release of a six-part docuseries on Netflix in 2022, Harry's memoir, \"Spare,\" hit bookshelves in 2023, quickly becoming a bestseller.\n\nBritish royal expert Hilary Fordwich told Fox News Digital that the king's seemingly too-busy schedule and William's new role are no accidents.\n\n\"One of the many ways we know how much the military has always meant to Prince Harry is that he wore his Blues and Royals military uniform when he wed Meghan ... back when he was Captain General of the Marines,\" Fordwich said. \"He has lost other military honorary titles: his Honorary Air Commandant of RAF Honington and Commodore in Chief, Small Ships and Diving, Royal Naval Command.\"\n\n\"Nothing the royal family does is either spur of the moment or by accident,\" she said. \"Nor do they act in isolation. ... What is so sad for Harry is that he was viewed by both the public and military as a rather courageous soldier. He didn't have to serve in Afghanistan. He had to fight government policy to be allowed to serve. ... It was considered too much of a security risk for him to see active duty.\"\n\n\"His reputation was further enhanced with his founding of the Invictus Games,\" Fordwich continued. \"But now his reputation is permanently tarnished.\"\n\n\"It's hard to imagine when a true reconciliation will ever occur,\" Andersen said, referring to Harry's strained relationship with his family.\n\nPRINCE HARRY WON'T MEET WITH KING CHARLES DURING TRIP TO UK FOR INVICTUS GAMES ANNIVERSARY\n\nModeled after the Warrior Games in the United States, Harry founded the Invictus Games in 2014 as a Paralympic-style event designed to inspire military veterans around the world as they work to overcome battlefield injuries. Harry was a former captain in the British Army.\n\nThe Invictus Games were created when the royal was patron of The Royal Foundation of The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and Prince Harry. {"uri": "8118743931", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:16:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:16:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:15:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/king-charles-gives-prince-harry-slap-face-announcement-refusing-see-son-expert", "title": "King Charles gives Prince Harry 'slap in the face' with announcement after refusing to see his son: expert", "body": "By entering your email and pushing continue, you are agreeing to Fox News' Terms of Use and Privacy Policy, which includes our Notice of Financial Incentive. To access the content, check your email and follow the instructions provided.\n\nPrince Harry was hit with two major blows during his return to the U.K.\n\nJust after learning that he would not be able to see his father due to the king's busy schedule, Buckingham Palace announced on Wednesday that Harry's brother, Prince William, will be made colonel in chief of the Army Air Corps. The Prince of Wales is succeeding King Charles III as head of the regiment.\n\nThe U.K.'s Independent noted that it's likely the honor would have been given to Harry, if he hadn't stepped down as a senior member of the royal family, because he served with the unit in Afghanistan. A spokesperson for Buckingham Palace didn't immediately respond to Fox News Digital's request for comment.\n\nPRINCE HARRY 'HIT HARD' BY KATE MIDDLETON CANCER BATTLE, BUT PRINCE WILLIAM WON'T LET HIM 'NEAR' WIFE: EXPERT\n\n\"It is one slap in the face after another for Harry,\" royal expert Ian Pelham Turner told Fox News Digital about the announcement, which some U.K. outlets have described as another \"snub\" for the prince.\n\n\"I think this is a mistake,\" said Pelham Turner about the king not choosing to meet with his son ahead of the bombshell news. \"Patronizing reasons like Harry might spill the beans on a conversation in any future book ... are not justified and will only add petrol to the flames. Charles ... [was] touchy feeling, holding hands with cancer victims but cannot stretch out to his son.\"\n\n\"Taking away another military regiment ... means nothing to the British public,\" Pelham Turner said. \"But it does to Harry. [It's] the regiment he served in until 2014. Giving it to William will only further highlight the churlish divisions and not show a forgiving nature. ... On a day when Harry is at an event to celebrate the Invictus Games ... I wonder what the recipients ... think of the betrayal.\"\n\nHarry, 39, arrived in London without his wife, Meghan Markle, by his side. The prince joined a panel on Tuesday for the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games. The discussion, \"The IGF Conversation: Realizing a Global Community,\" aimed to highlight service personnel and their families.\n\nThen on Wednesday, the Duke of Sussex appeared at St. Paul's Cathedral for a service commemorating the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games.\n\nOn that same day, Charles and his wife, Queen Camilla, welcomed thousands of guests to Buckingham Palace for the first garden party of 2024. The festivities are a longstanding tradition that dates to the 1860s. Other members of the royal family, including Princess Anne, Prince Edward, Sophie, the Duchess of Edinburgh, and the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester, were in attendance.\n\nCLICK HERE TO SIGN UP FOR THE ENTERTAINMENT NEWSLETTER\n\nA spokesperson for the Duke of Sussex previously confirmed to Fox News Digital that the prince wouldn't be meeting with his father.\n\n\"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not The Duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it, unfortunately, will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme,\" the statement said.\n\n\"The Duke, of course, is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nHarry's sister-in-law, Princess Kate Middleton, has been keeping a low profile as she seeks treatment for cancer. The king, 75, who was also diagnosed with cancer, has returned to public-facing duties as he continues his recovery.\n\nChristopher Andersen, author of \"The King,\" told Fox News Digital that the king and the Prince of Wales, 41, sent a clear message to Harry.\n\n\"If there were any doubts that Harry is dead to his father and brother, then this one-two punch from King Charles should dispel them once and for all,\" Andersen said. \"By announcing that he was too busy to see Harry, even though the two men are just two miles apart, and then officially giving Harry's colonel in chief of the Army Air Corps title to William - one of the honorary military titles Harry cherished most - the king is slamming the door in Harry's face.\"\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\n\"This was a calculated, even cruel snub,\" Andersen said. \"Under other circumstances, I would have chalked it up to the fatal tone-deafness that the palace is so famous for. But the king could easily have carved out time to see Harry, and the announcement giving Harry's old title to William didn't have to happen just as Harry arrived in London. This was all very deliberate and very petty - and very personal.\"\n\nAndersen said Harry has \"put up a good front\" as he remained dedicated to highlighting his passion project.\n\n\"Having to put up with so much emotional turmoil throughout his entire life, he has learned to compartmentalize,\" Andersen said. \"He certainly gave no indication that anything was wrong during the Invictus ceremonies. That doesn't mean that Harry isn't frustrated and, frankly, deeply wounded by the royals' continued intransigence.\"\n\n\"It's also very sad that the king and other senior royals have made no effort to embrace the Invictus Games,\" Andersen continued. \"Queen Elizabeth was a huge booster of Invictus and, in 2016, even did a memorable TV commercial for the games with Harry and Barack and Michelle Obama.\n\n\"You would think otherwise, given the king's health problems, not to mention Princess Kate's. This would be the perfect time for Charles to seize the olive branch being extended repeatedly by Harry. But the king and Prince William are not in a forgiving mood.\"\n\nHarry has had a troubled relationship with the royal family since he quit royal duties. According to the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, the unbearable intrusions and racist attitudes of the British media prompted the move to California in 2020.\n\nLIKE WHAT YOU'RE READING? CLICK HERE FOR MORE ENTERTAINMENT NEWS\n\nAfter their departure, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex aired their grievances about life as royals. In 2021, they sat down with Oprah Winfrey for an interview that was viewed by 50 million people globally. Following the release of a six-part docuseries on Netflix in 2022, Harry's memoir, \"Spare,\" hit bookshelves in 2023, quickly becoming a bestseller.\n\nBritish royal expert Hilary Fordwich told Fox News Digital that the king's seemingly too-busy schedule and William's new role are no accidents.\n\n\"One of the many ways we know how much the military has always meant to Prince Harry is that he wore his Blues and Royals military uniform when he wed Meghan ... back when he was Captain General of the Marines,\" Fordwich said. \"He has lost other military honorary titles: his Honorary Air Commandant of RAF Honington and Commodore in Chief, Small Ships and Diving, Royal Naval Command.\"\n\n\"Nothing the royal family does is either spur of the moment or by accident,\" she said. \"Nor do they act in isolation. ... What is so sad for Harry is that he was viewed by both the public and military as a rather courageous soldier. He didn't have to serve in Afghanistan. He had to fight government policy to be allowed to serve. ... It was considered too much of a security risk for him to see active duty.\"\n\n\"His reputation was further enhanced with his founding of the Invictus Games,\" Fordwich continued. \"But now his reputation is permanently tarnished.\"\n\n\"It's hard to imagine when a true reconciliation will ever occur,\" Andersen said, referring to Harry's strained relationship with his family.\n\nPRINCE HARRY WON'T MEET WITH KING CHARLES DURING TRIP TO UK FOR INVICTUS GAMES ANNIVERSARY\n\nModeled after the Warrior Games in the United States, Harry founded the Invictus Games in 2014 as a Paralympic-style event designed to inspire military veterans around the world as they work to overcome battlefield injuries.
