Pictured here with Earl Spencer (right) at the unveiling of Diana's statue in 2021\n\nCharles Spencer, Princess Diana, then Prince Charles, Lady Jane Fellowes and Lady Sarah McCorquodale in 1985\n\nDespite well-documented tensions with the Windsors, Prince Harry has remained close to his mother's family over the years - particularly Lady Jane.\n\nLady Jane, the middle of the three sisters, four years older than Diana, has long been seen as a confidante and a steadying influence in his life.\n\nRead More Prince Harry's brave face as he meets crowds leaving St Paul's Cathedral after Invictus Games service while King Charles hosts Buckingham Palace garden party as he was 'too busy' to see his son during his whistle-stop UK visit\n\nShe was asked to give a reading during Harry's wedding to Meghan in 2018 and was one of the first members to be invited to meet their infant son Archie - even before Prince William.\n\nThroughout his bombshell memoir Spare, he gave a 'stand out thanks' to Lady Jane, her elder sister Lady Sarah McCorquodale and Earl Spencer but failed to mention the late Queen, King Charles or his brother.\n\nIt is therefore little surprise that two of the siblings turned out at yesterday's ceremony to give support to Diana's youngest child.\n\nAs well as his aunt and uncle, Harry was surrounded by a number of dignitaries, politicians and close friends.\n\nHis lawyer David Sherbourne was in attendance while former army officer Mark Dyer - who helped mentor Harry particularly after his mother's death - was also in the congregation.\n\nRishi Sunak's wife Akshata Murty also joined the group, dressed in a military-style green coat with gold buttons, where she was joined by Minister of State for Veterans' Affairs Johnny Mercer.\n\nPrince Harry put on a brave face today as he left St Paul's Cathedral alone following a service to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games\n\nThe 9th Earl Spencer can be seen smiling and gesticulating as he walks up the steps to the historic English landmark\n\nThe estranged royal, who was met with cheers from the crowd, beamed as he shook hands and joked around with dozens of people who had lined up to greet him\n\nGuests attending the royal garden party at Buckingham Palace in London this afternoon\n\nOther stars within the crowd included former Olympic champion triple jumper Jonathan Edwards.\n\nHuge crowds had gathered outside St Paul's to catch a glimpse of the estranged royals rare appearance on British soil, with some shouting 'we love you Harry' as he walked out of his car.\n\nRead More Lady Jane Fellowes - the middle Spencer sister who broke the news of Diana's death to the rest of the family and remains an important steadying influence in Harry's life today\n\nThe Duke was warmly greeted by the Dean of St Paul's, the Very Reverend Andrew Tremlett, before being escorted to his seat under the cathedral's great dome.\n\nWhilst inside the cathedral he spoke to the clergy, as well as Earl Spencer before taking his seat.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex, who remains estranged from many family members after a string of attacks on the Royal Family in recent years, said on Tuesday that he had been told his father did not have time to see him this week while he is staying in the UK.\n\nCharles had not been able to find time to see his son Prince Harry this afternoon as he attends the first Buckingham Palace garden party of the summer season.\n\nThe King had a busy day yesterday with meetings planned in the morning ahead of the garden party. He then attended his weekly audience with the Prime Minister in the evening followed by a Privy Council meeting.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex has flown into London for the Invictus engagements and there were hopes that he would see the King. But a spokesman for Harry said that the monarch's 'full programme' meant the get-together would not happen.\n\nPrince Harry, Duke of Sussex waves as he arrives to attend a ceremony marking the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games\n\nBritain's Minister of State for Veterans' Affairs Johnny Mercer (L) and Akshata Murty, wife of Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, arrive to attend the ceremony\n\nDavid Sherborne, Britain's Prince Harry's lawyer, arrives at St Paul's this afternoon\n\nFormer Army officer Mark Dyer, who acted as the duke's mentor, playing the role of a supportive big brother figure for Harry after Diana's death, arrives at the ceremony\n\nYet royal insiders last night told the Telegraph that no formal requests for a meeting with the King had been made.\n\nDuring the ceremony Harry took a seat next to his mentor Mark Dyer and exchanged a few words with his uncle Earl Spencer.\n\nRead More King Charles was 'delighted' and 'playful' at garden party at Buckingham Palace - while a 'solitary' and 'wary' Harry attended Invictus service just two miles away, body language expert claims\n\nThe service began with the hymn Praise My Soul The King Of Heaven as a few miles away the King hosted the first Buckingham Palace garden party of the year.\n\nThe Dean of St Paul's told the congregation: 'We gather this evening to offer grateful thanksgiving to Almighty God for the work of the Invictus Games Foundation, and in this their 10th anniversary year, we celebrate the tremendous achievements of the numerous competitors across 23 nations.\n\n'We give thanks for the inspiring vision and compassion that formed the foundation and, chiefly, for the resultant decade of profound and transformational work.\n\n'We lament the pain, cost and indignity of war and terror, and pray for a world where justice shall reign and where the nations will find their longed for unity.\n\n'We recall, with admiration, the skill and determination of those who seek to repair, rehabilitate, and reclaim the lives of those living with serious illness or injury: changing and saving lives.'\n\nHe gave a reading from 1 Corinthians 12 4-11. Actor Damian Lewis, 53, meanwhile read out the Invictus poem with the service being conducted by William Ernest Henley.\n\nAn emotional reading was also given by Michelle Turner who is the UK Invictus Games Team vice-captain. She read a personal poem about how the games had helped her recovery and impacted her family.\n\nOther stars among the crowd included former Olympic champion triple jumper Jonathan Edwards\n\nMembers of the public wait to see Britain's Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex arrive to attend the ceremony\n\nAt the end of the reading she tearfully said: 'Thank you Invictus, for giving me my life back.'\n\nAs he left the cathedral on a balmy evening in the capital, the Californian-based royal greeted large crowds.\n\nHe was heard asking two fans from New York what had brought them to the UK. When they responded they were here for a wedding, the Prince jokingly asked it was 'in there?' referring to St Paul's Cathedral.\n\nThe Duke joked around with one enthusiastic royal fan who had her arms outstretched with two phones to try and get the best shot of Harry.\n\n'Why have you got 2 phones?' he laughed, 'it doesn't make sense!'\n\nHundreds of people had joined the crowd that was tightly guarded by police officers.\n\nShouts of 'we love you Harry' could be heard as the Prince did his walkabout, while others screamed with excitement until Harry got into a Land Rover and drove off.\n\nPrince Harry arrives to attend the Invictus Games Foundation 10th Anniversary Service of Thanksgiving at St Paul's Cathedral\n\nKing Charles III speaks to guests as he hosts a Royal Garden Party at Buckingham Palace in central London\n\nHarry arriving at St Paul's Cathedral for a service to celebrate the 10th anniversary of his Invictus Games\n\nThe Duke joked around with one enthusiastic royal fan who had her arms outstretched with two phones to try and get the best shot of Harry\n\nKing Charles III speaks to guests attending the garden party at Buckingham Palace today\n\nIt is not known where Harry is staying while in Britain as he now has no official home after being asked to leave Frogmore Cottage.\n\nHe is expected to stay in the UK until tomorrow before flying to Nigeria where he will meet up with Meghan for a quasi-royal tour that is also expected to highlight the Invictus Games.\n\nHarry spent Tuesday in the capital attending a summit that reflected on the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games, which stages sporting events for wounded, sick or injured veterans or serving military to aid their recovery.\n\nHe told delegates at the event, held at the Honourable Artillery Company's headquarters on the edge of the City of London: 'Sometimes you... look back and go 'Look at what we've done'.\n\n'But also given the state of the world, there is so much more to do and I think a lot of uncertainty - but what we've created is a global community.'\n\nKing Charles III (centre) and Queen Camilla walk out to join the crowds at the wears his medals as he attends the Invictus Games Foundation's 10th Anniversary celebration\n\nThe King, Queen, Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh, the Princess Royal and the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester arrive together for the garden party\n\nKing Charles III speaks to guests attending a Royal Garden Party at Buckingham Palace\n\nQueen Camilla speaks to guests attending a Royal Garden Party at Buckingham Palace\n\nHarry is also not expected to see his estranged brother Prince William who held an investiture ceremony at Windsor Castle yesterday.\n\nWilliam continues to balance work with looking after his three children while his wife Kate undergoes preventative chemotherapy for cancer and recovers from serious abdominal surgery in January.\n\nToday William will fly to Cornwall for further official engagements - and the King will meet staff and families of the 3 Royal School of Military Engineering in Surrey.\n\nThen on Monday there will be a rare joint visit for Charles and William, as the King officially hands over the role of Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps to William at the Army Aviation Centre in Middle Wallop, where Harry previously learnt to fly.\n\nHarry has travelled to the UK to commemorate the Invictus Games milestone with those who have been involved with the paralympic-style tournament and mark the decade-long support competitors have received.\n\nCharles and Harry last met soon after the King announced his cancer diagnosis in February and his son rushed from America to see his father.\n\nThat was the first time Harry had seen his father in person for 17 months, and they had a half-hour meeting before Charles left London to recuperate at Sandringham following treatment.\n\nBut this time, a spokesman for Harry said: 'In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme.\n\nThe Duke was warmly greeted by the Dean of St Paul's, the Very Reverend Andrew Tremlett, before being escorted to his seat under the cathedral's great dome\n\nMark Dyer during The priorities and hopes to see him soon.'\n\nJust hours after Harry's statement, palace officials announced a new joint engagement for Charles and William.\n\nIt is one of dozens of official engagements being planned for the 75-year-old monarch in the coming months after his doctors gave him the all-clear to undertake more public work once again while continuing his cancer treatment.\n\nOn Monday, Charles met the prime minister of the Republic of Fiji at Buckingham Palace, before retiring to Clarence House - three miles away from Harry's event.\n\nHarry now lives with his wife Meghan Markle and Arriving at St. Paul's Cathedral today, he was greeted with cheers from the assembled crowd. Victoria Murphy, a contributing editor for Town & Country, captured the moment.\n\nWhile no other members of the royal family were present with Harry, relatives from his late mother Princess Diana's side, including her brother Charles Spencer and sister Lady Jane Fellowes, attended the event. Additionally, Harry's cousins Lara Spencer, Louis Spencer, and George McCorquodale were seen entering the cathedral.\n\nDespite relocating to the United States in 2020, Harry has maintained close ties with his Spencer family. During his visit to the UK for Queen Elizabeth II's funeral in September 2022, he and Duchess Meghan visited Althorp, Diana's childhood home, spent time with relatives, and visited Diana's grave. Diana's sisters, Lady Jane and Lady Sarah McCorquodale, were reportedly present at the christening of Harry's daughter, Princess Lillibet, in March 2023.\n\nIn other news from London, King Charles III hosted the first Garden Party of the year at Buckingham Palace, attended by several senior working royals including Queen Camilla, Princess Anne, Prince Edward, and Sophie, Duchess of Edinburgh.\n\nAccording to a spokesperson for the Duke of Sussex, Harry will not be able to meet with King Charles during his visit this week due to the King's busy schedule. The spokesperson expressed Harry's understanding of his father's commitments and expressed hope for a future meeting. Additionally, it's unlikely that Harry will see his brother, Prince William, as the two remain estranged.\n\nPrince Harry's stay in London will be brief as he is scheduled to depart on Thursday to join his wife Meghan for their trip to Nigeria. {"uri": "8117758102", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:42:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:42:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:42:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://people.com/why-royal-family-did-not-attend-prince-harry-invictus-games-service-london-8643906", "title": "Why the Royal Family Did Not Attend Prince Harry's Invictus Games Service in London", "body": "Prince Harry's service in London to mark the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games did not bring together members of the royal family.\n\nAs the Duke of Sussex, 39, attended a Service of Thanksgiving at St. Paul's Cathedral on May 8, family members including King Charles, Prince William and Kate Middleton were not in attendance.\n\nPrince Harry traveled to the U.K. from his California home to mark the 10th anniversary of the international adaptive sports tournament for wounded, injured and sick service personnel and veterans, which he founded in 2014.\n\nEarlier this week, it was disclosed that Harry wouldn't be able to meet with his father King Charles during his time in the U.K. due to the monarch's \"full\" schedule -- which includes the palace garden party hosted by the King at the same time, just a few miles away at Buckingham Palace. Along with Charles and Queen Camilla, the garden party was also attended by royal family members Princess Anne, Prince Edward and his wife Sophie, Duchess of Edinburgh and the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester.\n\n\"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not The Duke will meet with his father while in the U.K. this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full program. The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon,\" a spokesperson for the Duke of Sussex said on May 7.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex also traveled to the U.K. in February to privately visit his father the King after Buckingham Palace announced the monarch's cancer diagnosis. King Charles postponed public-facing duties and continued to work behind the scenes after he started receiving treatment, which the palace said coincided with its Feb. 5 announcement about his health. King Charles resumed forward-facing duties on April 30, and Queen Camilla later said she thought her husband was \"really thrilled to be out.\"\n\nPrince Harry's February trip to the U.K. did not involve meeting with his brother, Prince William, or his sister-in-law, Princess Kate. A royal source said at the time there were \"no plans\" for the brothers to get together.\n\nIn March, the Princess of Wales, 42, announced that she was undergoing treatment for cancer following abdominal surgery in January. PEOPLE understands that Prince Harry and Meghan Markle privately reached out to the Prince and Princess of Wales amid Kate's diagnosis.\n\nThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex also shared their support by releasing a statement after Princess Kate announced the news about her health.\n\n\"We wish health and healing for Kate and the family, and hope they are able to do so privately and in peace,\" the Duke and Duchess of Sussex said in a statement shared with PEOPLE on March 22, the day of Princess Kate's announcement.\n\nBefore the Princess of Wales announced that she had cancer, a family source told PEOPLE that Prince Harry and Meghan were in the dark about her abdominal surgery and recovery.\n\n\"They are aware of everything that goes on back in England, but are being left out of any details regarding Kate,\" the source told PEOPLE. \"There is clearly no trust.\"\n\nThe itinerary for Prince Harry's Invictus-focused trip also included a panel discussion, and the Duke of Sussex delivered a reading at St. Paul's Cathedral during the Service of Thanksgiving.\n\nHomeland actor Damian Lewis recited the poem \"Invictus,\" which inspired the competition's motto, and the ceremony was attended by representatives from across the participating nations of the Invictus Games, including members of the wounded, injured and sick service personnel and veteran community. Community members, supporters and beneficiaries also gave readings in the service led by The Very Reverend Andrew Tremlett, Dean of St. Paul's.\n\nCan't get enough of PEOPLE's Royals coverage? Sign up for our free Royals newsletter to get the latest updates on Kate Middleton, Meghan Markle and more!\n\nPrince Harry's latest U.K. trip was announced on April 28, and he made the journey without his wife Meghan, 42, though they are soon due to reunite. PEOPLE confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex will travel to Nigeria later this week upon the invitation on behalf of the Chief of Defense Staff, the country's highest-ranking military official.\n\nDuring their visit, Prince Harry and Meghan will meet with service members and participate in a variety of cultural activities in a visit highlighting the Invictus Games. Nigeria made its event debut at the sixth cycle of the adaptive sports tournament in D\u00fcsseldorf, Germany in September 2023, and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex spent time with the team and fans in the stands.\n\nPrince Harry joked that his wife was rooting for the squad at the opening ceremony after discovering that she has Nigerian heritage, a revelation made on her Archetypes podcast in 2022. Nigerian Minister of Defense Alhaji Mohammed Abubakar Badaru also attended the competition in Germany, and has expressed interest in hosting the Invictus Games in the future, should the country be granted the opportunity.\n\nWhile plans are in motion for the next Invictus Games in Vancouver and Whistler, Canada, in February 2025, the eighth iteration of the Invictus Games might take it back to the United States. On May 1, the Invictus Games Foundation revealed the shortlist of cities hoping to host the 2027 Invictus Games, with just two contenders: Washington, D.C. and Birmingham, U.K.\n\nThe 2027 cycle will be the eighth Invictus Games, following the competitions in London (2014), Orlando (2016), Toronto (2017), Sydney (2018), The Hague (2022, bumped from 2020 due to the pandemic) and D\u00fcsseldorf in For weeks, talks of a father-son reunion between the British monarch and his estranged son have flooded the media. In fact, the only uncertainty surrounding the visit was whether or not the Duke of Sussex would bring his wife Meghan Markle, and kids along for the family rendezvous. It turns out that not only did the rest of the Sussexes fail to tag along for the UK visit, but Prince Harry's reunion with his dad never happened.\n\nEarlier, a spokesperson for Prince Harry confirmed that the meeting between the prince and King Charles would not be possible. They attributed the shocking turn of events to \"His Majesty's full program.\" On Harry's part, the prince took the situation well, with the rep explaining how much he understood \"his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities.\"\n\nDespite the royals' claims of having too many commitments, royal expert Charlotte Griffiths had a different theory. According to her, King Charles declined to see his son Harry because the Prince made certain unattainable demands. She divulged,\n\n\"I think the reason was because Harry made certain demands about who could be in the room and who couldn't. Although on the surface it looks like a snub, Harry made it very difficult for his father.\"\n\nExplaining further, Charlotte noted that other forces may have influenced King Charles' decision to snub Prince Harry during his latest UK visit. She added,\n\n\"William may have had a thought about how this meeting should be conducted or whether it should be conducted at all.\"\n\nWhile Prince Harry couldn't get the chance to reunite with his dad, brother or other British royals, he enjoyed the support of his mom Princess Diana's family at the Invictus Games event. As the royals attended the season's first garden party at Buckingham Palace, Harry's maternal family including Princess Diana's siblings Earl Spencer and Lady Jane Fellowes joined him at the service at St. Paul's Cathedral. Meghan did not join Harry at the event, with the Royal Family also deciding against attending, despite getting invited.\n\nHowever, Earl Charles Spencer and Lady Jane Fellowes, both siblings of the late Princess Diana, Harry's mother, turned up to support their nephew at St Paul's last night. And Harry gave his aunt and uncle warm hugs as they attended the event, with them looking content in each other's company.\n\nFor all the latest on news, politics, sports, and showbiz from the USA, go to The Mirror US.\n\nREAD MORE: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle to have bombshells exposed in upcoming German documentary\n\nHarry was supported by his aunt and uncle at the event Earl Spencer has long been close with Harry\n\nDespite the ongoing royal rift with the Windsors, Prince Harry has remained close to his mother's side of the family. The Duke of Sussex is quite close to his aunt Lady Jane, who is the middle of the three sisters.\n\nLady Jane is four years older than Diana and has long been seen as a confidante and a steadying influence in Prince Harry's life. And the Duke is also close to his other aunt, Lady Sarah McCorquodale, by all accounts.\n\n\"He clearly has quite a good relationship with Charles Spencer, Jane and Sarah on the maternal side,\" historian Tessa Dunlop revealed previously in an interview with OK! from June 2023. He beamed as he shook hands and chatted with several of them.\n\n\"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not The Duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full program,\" the spokesperson said.\n\nAlthough Charles, 75, and other members of Harry's family weren't able to attend the anniversary celebrations, a source exclusively told Us earlier this month that Harry had attempted to contact his family and invite them to the Games.\n\nThe insider added that Harry and his brother, Prince William, \"haven't had a real conversation in months,\" although Harry \"would be more than happy\" to reconnect.\n\nHarry's tension with his father and brother goes back to 2020 when he and his wife, Meghan Markle, stepped down as working senior royals and moved to the United States with their son Archie, now 5. London, but no royal reunion with King Charles | Life", "body": "The absence of a meeting between Harry and his family is interpreted as a snub, highlighted by Prince William's appointment as colonel-in-chief of Harry's former regiment.\n\nPrince Harry was in London on Wednesday to mark the 10th anniversary of his Invictus Games for wounded military veterans, but no meeting was scheduled with his estranged father King Charles III.\n\nAs with all his trips to the UK since he moved to the United States in 2020, his three-day visit to the British capital has sparked a fresh round of speculation about a reconciliation with his family.\n\nA possible end to four years of rancour and score-settling was seen as on the cards in February, when Harry jetted in from California to briefly see his father after it was announced that he had cancer.\n\nBut the palace doors look firmly shut to him this time round.\n\nA spokesman for the Duke of Sussex, as Harry is also known, said on Wednesday that a meeting this week \"will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme\".\n\nHe added:\n\nThe king's \"diary of commitments\" has been less full than usual in recent months, as Charles, 75, receives chemotherapy for cancer.\n\nBut it is filling up again after doctors said they were \"very encouraged\" by the progress of his treatment, allowing him to ease back into official public engagements.\n\nREAD | King Charles resumes public engagements with visit to cancer centre\n\nOn Tuesday, the king was pictured meeting Fiji Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka at Buckingham Palace, as Harry attended a discussion on the Invictus Games in London's financial district.\n\nOn Wednesday, the British head of state attended the first garden party of the year at Buckingham Palace, while Harry was just under three miles (five kilometres) away at St Paul's Cathedral.\n\nThe majestic dome of St Paul's was where Charles married Harry's mother, Princess Diana, in 1981.\n\nOutside the church, one onlooker told AFP the king was \"quite right\" not to agree to meet, suggesting Harry was on a publicity trip and acting as if he was still a working royal.\n\n\"I think they're quite right to say, 'no meeting'. Can't have it both ways,\" they said.\n\nBut one woman, who gave her name as Tracy, said she was a fan and suggested public opinion was being manipulated by the media against Harry.\n\n\"At the end of the day, we don't know if there's any truth in what they've been saying. But if there's any truth in it, I think it's sad,\" she said.\n\nThe lack of meeting - even for a short time - has been interpreted as a snub for Harry, compounded by an announcement that Charles will appoint his elder son and heir Prince William as colonel-in-chief of Harry's old regiment.\n\nFormer army captain Harry served as a helicopter pilot with the Army Air Corps in Afghanistan.\n\nNo meeting is planned either with William, who is due on a visit to Cornwall in southwest England, and the Isles of Scilly on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWilliam's wife Catherine is also undergoing cancer treatment and has not made any public appearance since December last year.\n\nThe brothers, once close, are reportedly no longer on speaking terms due to Harry's criticisms of royal life in a succession of high-profile interviews, TV documentaries and his autobiography.\n\nAfter Harry's three-day visit, he is due to join Meghan on a trip to Nigeria.\n\nREAD MORE | Harry and Meghan's Nigerian visit: Roots inspire royal visit and future Invictus Games glory\n\nHarry, 39, was characterised by the British media as a \"party prince\", who had none of the responsibilities of William, 41, who will become king after Charles.\n\nBut since marrying Meghan, an American former television actress, and quitting royal life, he has faced a sustained backlash in the UK, led by the tabloid press.\n\nFormer Daily Mirror editor and CNN host Piers Morgan, one of the most vocal critics of the couple, said Charles had given \"a big regal middle finger to his treacherous younger son\".\n\n\"It's clear from his 'scheduling issue' that Charles would rather impale himself on a rusty sword than meet up with someone who has wrought such vengeful misery on the royal family for so Wounded, injured and sick military personnel compete in multiple sports at the event. {"uri": "8117715595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:11:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:11:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:11:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.ok.co.uk/royal/breaking-prince-harry-invictus-games-32762358", "title": "Prince Harry marks Invictus Games anniversary at service after Charles 'snub'", "body": "The Duke of Sussex has arrived at the service of thanksgiving at London's St Paul's Cathedral to celebrate the 10th anniversary of his Invictus Games.\n\nHarry, 39, has travelled back to the UK to commemorate the milestone with members of the Invictus Games family and mark the decade-long support competitors in the paralympic-style tournament have received.\n\nHe has not been joined on the trip by his wife Meghan Markle or their children, Archie and Lilibet.\n\nDuring the service, Harry will give a reading and actor Damian Lewis will recite the Invictus poem.\n\nThere was speculation that Harry would see his father, King Charles, during his visit to the UK, but a spokesman for Harry confirmed on Tuesday, 7 May, that the monarch, 75, had a \"full programme\" and a meeting would not happen.\n\nCharles and Harry last met soon after the King announced his cancer diagnosis in February and his son, who now lives with his family in California, rushed from America to see his father.\n\nA spokesperson for Harry said: \"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it soon.\"\n\nIt is thought that King Charles has been receiving his cancer treatment as an outpatient midweek and he hosted the first Buckingham Palace garden party of the season on {"uri": "8117870575", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:09:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:09:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:09:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.marieclaire.com/celebrity/royals/princess-dianas-siblings-support-prince-harry/", "title": "With No Royals In Sight, Prince Harry Is Supported By Princess Diana's Siblings at Invictus Games Event in London", "body": "The Spencer siblings stepped up to make sure that Harry had family on hand at his milestone celebration.\n\nWhen Princess Diana's brother Charles Spencer eulogized his sister at her funeral at Westminster Abbey on September 6, 1997, he made a pledge to her regarding her beloved sons, Prince William and Prince Harry: \"I pledge that we, your blood family, will do all we can to continue the imaginative way in which you were steering these two exceptional young men so that their souls are not simply immersed by duty and tradition, but can sing openly, as you planned,\" he said, as the world watched. \"We fully respect the heritage into which they have both been born and will always respect and encourage them in their royal role but we, like you, recognize the need for them to experience as many different aspects of life as possible to arm them spiritually and emotionally for the years ahead. I know you would have expected nothing less from us.\"\n\nAs King Charles attended a garden party roughly three miles away this evening, his younger son, Prince Harry, was at St. Paul's Cathedral -- interestingly, the location of Charles and Diana's wedding in 1981 -- to celebrate 10 years of the Invictus Games, Harry's passion project and the work of his life. The King turned down the opportunity to meet with Harry while his son was in the U.K., citing a busy schedule, Harry's spokesperson confirmed yesterday; no members of the royal family turned up to Harry's Service of Thanksgiving.\n\nBut then, the Spencer family swooped in. Diana was one of four Spencer siblings -- she had two older sisters, Sarah and Jane, and a younger brother, Charles. Hello reports that Jane (now Lady Jane Fellowes) and Charles (more formally, Earl Charles Spencer) were in attendance at Harry's service, and arrived together \"with the pair sharing a smile,\" the outlet reports. Sarah (now Lady Sarah McCorquodale) was also in attendance, Hello reports.\n\nWhen Harry arrived at St. Paul's, he too was smiling and \"waving at cheering members of the crowd that had amassed,\" Hello reports. Inside, 1,000 people gathered for the ceremony, and \"Harry was clearly buoyed by the show of support from Charles, Lady Sarah, and Lady Jane,\" the publication added.\n\nSpeaking to Hello about Harry's attendance at the service, David Wiseman, a former competitor in the Games, said \"We wouldn't be here without Prince Harry, would we? We wouldn't be here without his initial vision, without his drive, without his influence, without his ability to convene this international community of those who have served and continue to serve. And he's so passionate about serving that community. He's one of us -- he's part of this community, and we're incredibly proud to have him as part of it. We're delighted he's here to help us celebrate the past 10 years, and to look forward to the next 10 years.\"\n\nHarry founded the Games in 2014 as a multi-sport event for injured or sick service personnel, both veterans and those still actively serving. With no members of the royal family there and his wife, Meghan Markle, back at home in the U.S., \"fans had been worried Harry would be at the service alone,\" The Mirror reports -- but should feel hopeful that Harry did, indeed, have family there, after all. (Somewhere, surely, Diana is smiling.)\n\nOf the Games, Harry said this week \"Sometimes you...look back and go, 'Look at what we've done,'\" he said. \"But also, given the state of the world, there is so much more to do, and I think a lot of uncertainty -- but what we've created is a global community.\" When asked about the future of the Games, Harry confirmed they would continue so long as they \"serve their purpose,\" he said.\n\nHarry will next join up with Meghan in Nigeria, where they will discuss possible future opportunities for the country to host a future iteration of the Games.", "source": {"uri": "marieclaire.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Marie Claire"}, "authors": [{"uri": "rachel_burchfield@marieclaire.com", "name": "Rachel Burchfield", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_Harry,_Duke_of_Sussex", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Spencer,_9th_Earl_Spencer", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Charles Spencer, 9th Earl Spencer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lady_Sarah_McCorquodale", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lady Sarah McCorquodale"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diana,_Princess_of_Wales", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Diana, Princess of Wales"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_I_of_England", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Charles I of England"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hello!_(magazine)", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Hello! The monarch was also due to carry out an engagement at a military training base on Thursday.\n\nIt meant Harry was the only royal figure at St Paul's for the gathering to celebrate the international sporting event that he founded in 2014 for military personnel wounded in action.\n\nHarry, who arrived alone, smiling and waving to a crowd outside, was to provide a reading, with actor Damian Lewis reciting a poem to the congregation which included veterans and wounded service personnel.\n\nAfter leaving Britain, Harry will be joined by his wife Meghan, who did not come with him to London, for a visit to Nigeria.\n\n(Reporting by Michael Holden, editing by William James)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": busy to meet with the 39-year-old while he's in town.\n\nBut while royal watchers are speculating this is an intentional \"snub\" by the British Monarch of his son, a spokesperson has confirmed the young prince completely understands.\n\nREAD MORE: King Charles 'too busy' to see Prince Harry during London visit\n\n\"Prince Harry's spokesperson gave me a statement yesterday about the fact that he was very understanding that his father couldn't see him,\" GB News royal correspondent, Cameron Walker, told Today.\n\n\"It was a far-flung away from a statement I would expect to receive from the {"uri": "2024-05-349479273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "20:33:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T20:33:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T20:23:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://ca.style.yahoo.com/king-prince-harry-were-less-202332142.html", "title": "The King and Prince Harry were less than three miles apart but the gulf has never been more obvious", "body": "At Buckingham Palace, the King stepped out in front of 8,000 guests at his first garden party since his cancer diagnosis. Across town shortly afterwards, the Duke of Sussex took his place at St Paul's Cathedral for a service celebrating 10 years of the Invictus Games.\n\nFather and son were less than three miles away from one another, but have never seemed further apart.\n\nAt the side of the King was a Royal family out in force: the Queen, the Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh, the Princess Royal and the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester all taking their place for the national anthem.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex arrived at his event alone.\n\nHowever, inside St Paul's Prince Harry had a team of his own in the shape of his maternal family. His uncle and aunt, Earl Spencer and Lady Jane Fellowes, there in support, greeted with emotional hugs.\n\nThey were joined by Mark Dyer, a former Army officer often described as a \"father figure\", Jamie Lowther-Pinkerton, a former private secretary to both Prince William and Prince Harry, and - in a sign of the times - David Sherborne, the Duke's barrister.\n\nOutside St Paul's, a crowd waited for a Prince Harry walkabout, taking selfies and clasping his hand as he made his way along.\n\nThe Prince of Wales did not attend either event, spending the morning holding a Windsor Castle investiture before returning home to his own family.\n\nThe separate outings show the state of the Royal family as it stands: Team Windsor on duty and an emerging Team Sussex elsewhere.\n\nIt was all a long way from scenes a decade ago, when Princes Charles, William and Harry celebrated the first Invictus Games in London with public appearances that saw them laughing, kissing on the cheek and sharing a joke looking at a phone screen.\n\nAt the 10th anniversary service on Wednesday, Prince Harry read 1 Corinthians 12: 4-11, to speak of \"service\" and the \"common good\".\n\nThe dean, the Very Rev Andrew Tremlett, gave a welcome hailing the tremendous achievements of the sick and injured military personnel from 23 nations who compete in the Games. Actor Damian Lewis, 53, recited the Invictus poem by William Henley.\n\nPrince Harry, who beamed and waved as he entered St Paul's, later joined Invictus competitors and staff for a reception in the cathedral's crypt. He spent the rest of the day in meetings with his remaining UK patronages.\n\nAt Buckingham Palace, in overlapping events, the King led the Royal family in the annual celebration of community service, his first garden party since his cancer diagnosis.\n\nAs he stood on the terrace with the Queen he heard a loud cheer at the end of the national anthem and waved his black top hat to acknowledge the crowd with thanks.\n\nWalking across the lawn, he shook hand after hand and answered the questions about his health repeatedly.\n\nOne guest told him he was \"looking so much better\". The King replied: \"I'm not doing badly.\"\n\n\"How are you feeling, Sir?\" one man asked, with the King saying \"Not too bad\" in response.\n\nThe King, wearing sunscreen in the heat, occasionally dabbed his nose with a handkerchief, but was described by an onlooker as seeming in excellent spirits, peppering guests with questions about where they had come from and what they did.\n\nIt is his next step towards resuming a regular programme of public activity, even as he continues his cancer treatment.\n\nAs such, the garden party, just like the Invictus service, should have been celebratory. Instead, the day was overshadowed somewhat by the rumbling question of the King and his younger son meeting. In the end, sources said, they did not.\n\nThe Duke had hoped for a meeting with his father before his trip to Britain, it is said, though recollections seem to vary once again as to whether a formal, timely request was made.\n\nEventually, as he landed on Tuesday morning, Harry's spokeswoman issued a written statement confirming that the King would be too busy to see his younger son. \"The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon,\" she said.\n\nA spokesman for the King said nothing.\n\nThose within the palace have privately raised the issue of trust, pointing to a King who has a lot on his plate.\n\nThe last time Prince Harry visited, for a 30-minute meeting shortly after the King was diagnosed with cancer, it was swiftly followed by an interview on US breakfast television.\n\nAt the time his actual words were received calmly back in Britain, but that he was open to being asked about it on Good Morning America did nothing to restore trust for future visits.\n\nThis week, within days, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex will arrive in Nigeria for a tour with all the attendant press and publicity that entails.\n\nThey are there in part to promote Invictus, in a country the Duchess has recently claimed a personal link to. She is, she said in a 2022 podcast, 43 per cent Nigerian according to a genealogy test.\n\nThe King, who is Head of Commonwealth but has not been able to travel overseas in 2024, will be kept informed of their activities.\n\nPerhaps on a different visit to the UK, when the Duke is not about to fly immediately into a high-profile, headline-grabbing Commonwealth tour, there will be time for father and son to talk quietly.\n\nThe explanation of being \"too busy\", volunteered by the Sussexes rather than the palace, has inevitably raised eyebrows. The King is busy, there is no doubting that, particularly as he navigates his return to public duty. The palace way of arranging meetings is formal, the lines of communication with the Sussexes limited. But where there's a will there's a way.\n\nIn February 2024, after his last visit to Britain, when asked whether it was possible that his father's illness would have a \"galvanising and sort of reunifying effect\" for his family, Prince Harry said: \"I'm sure.\"\n\nThree months on, another flying visit under his belt, and that dream is no closer to reality.\n\nThe gulf between Prince Harry and the King, in communication and expectation, seems no closer to being bridged.\n\nIt was not so long ago that another father and son had their differences aired; a young Prince Charles cast in the public imagination as the overly emotional son with a father who did not understand him.\n\n\"He's a romantic and I'm a pragmatist,\" Prince Philip once said of his eldest. \"That means we do see things differently.\"\n\nNo one would call the current King \"unfeeling\", as was said of his own late father. But perhaps, in all of this upset, he has found his inner pragmatist too.", "source": {"uri": "ca.style.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo!"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-349283264", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:36:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:36:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:18:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.aol.com/prince-harry-steps-london-invictus-161810780.html", "title": "Prince Harry Steps Out in London for Invictus Games Service as Royal Family Attends a Different Event Just Miles Away", "body": "Prince Harry Steps Out in London for Invictus Games Service as Royal Family Attends a Different Event Just Miles AwayJanine HenniMay 8, 2024 at 6:18 PM\n\nThe Duke of Sussex will take the mic at the meaningful service\n\nPrince Harry is in London for a cause close to his heart: the Invictus Games.\n\nOn May 8, the Duke of Sussex arrived at St. Paul's Cathedral -- where his parents King Charles and Princess Diana wed in 1981 -- for a service commemorating the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games. Prince Harry, 39, founded the adaptive sports tournament for service personnel and veterans in 2014, and the inaugural Invictus Games were held in London in September 2014.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex's latest trip to the U.K. was announced on April 28. He is due to deliver a reading as part of the program, while Homeland actor Damian Lewis will recite the poem \"Invictus.\"\n\nNotably, no other royal family members were expected to attend the service. Earlier this week, it was revealed that Harry wouldn't meet with his father Charles during his visit to the U.K. due to the monarch's \"full\" schedule.\n\nThe Service of Thanksgiving also coincided with the first garden party of the season at Buckingham Palace, which was attended by King Charles, Queen Camilla, Princess Anne, Prince Richard, and Birgitte, the Duchess of Gloucester.\n\nRelated: Meghan Markle Won't Join Prince Harry in the U.K. Next Month Before Heading to Nigeria Together\n\nThe \"Invictus\" poem by William Ernest Henley set to be read is full of meaning for the Invictus Games community. Invictus means \"unconquered\" in Latin, and the competition's motto \"I am\" comes from the poem published in 1888; it memorably ends with the lines, \"I am the master of my fate, I am the captain of my soul.\"\n\n\"The poem is a reminder that you have the power to take control of your life,\" Prince Harry told PEOPLE in 2022.\n\nThere happens to be a bust of Henley in the Crypt of St. Paul's Cathedral, where the service will bring together representatives from across the competition's participating nations, including members of the wounded, injured and sick service personnel and veteran community. Community members, supporters and beneficiaries will also give readings and participate in the program led by the Dean of St. Paul's, The Very Reverend Andrew Tremlett.\n\nHarry made the Invictus-focused trip to the U.K. without his wife, Meghan Markle, who will join him for the second leg of a trip abroad from their California home where they live with their children, Prince Archie, 5, and Princess Lilibet, 2. PEOPLE confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex have accepted an invitation to visit Nigeria on behalf of its Chief of Defense Staff, the highest-ranking military official, and the couple's visit there will also spotlight the Invictus Games.\n\nRelated: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry to Visit Nigeria in May for a Special Reason\n\nNigeria made its event debut at the latest Invictus Games in D\u00fcsseldorf, Germany in September 2023, where Prince Harry revealed in his opening ceremony speech that his wife was rooting for the team after discovering her Nigerian heritage.\n\nThe country's Minister of Defense, Alhaji Mohammed Abubakar Badaru also attended the tournament in Germany and has expressed willingness to host the games should Nigeria be granted the opportunity.\n\nThe D\u00fcsseldorf games marked Invictus' sixth cycle, following competitions in London (2014), Orlando (2016), Toronto (2017), Sydney (2018) and The Hague (2022, bumped from 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic). The next event is set for Vancouver and Whistler, Canada, in 2025, which will mark the debut of winter sports -- some of which the Duke of Sussex personally tried during the One Year to Go countdown event in Canada in February.\n\nCan't get enough of PEOPLE's Royals coverage? Sign up for our free Royals newsletter to get the latest updates on Kate Middleton, Meghan Markle and more!\n\nWhile speaking to PEOPLE in 2022, Prince Harry credited the Invictus community as \"a major part of my growth and learning.\"\n\n\"Creating the Games involved listening to military and veteran families -- and hearing directly from them about their lives -- and that offered so much perspective. It's been a lesson in serving a purpose greater than ourselves, and the benefit that comes from that extends to both the individual and the community\" the Duke of Sussex said at the thime. \"I truly believe that we are at our best when we're in service to others, and Invictus is all about upholding that value.\"\n\nFor more People news, make sure to sign up for our newsletter!\n\nRead the The monarch was also due to carry out an engagement at a military training base on Thursday.\n\nIt meant Harry was the only royal figure at St Paul's for the gathering to celebrate the international sporting event that he founded in 2014 for military personnel wounded in action.\n\nHarry, who arrived alone, smiling and waving to a crowd outside, was to provide a reading, with actor Damian Lewis reciting a poem to the congregation which included veterans and wounded service personnel.\n\nAfter leaving Britain, Harry will be joined by his wife Meghan, who did not come with him to London, for a visit to Nigeria. {"uri": "2024-05-349743837", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:27:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:27:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T04:05:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.nysun.com/article/king-charles-too-busy-to-see-prince-harry-in-harsh-message-of-rejection-as-meghan-hires-new-pr-pro-to-fix-her-appalling-public-image", "title": "'Too Busy' King Charles Won't See Prince Harry During London Trip", "body": "A representative of the Duke of Sussex said father and son can't meet during Harry's London visit because of King Charles' busy schedule.\n\nHopes of repairing a strained relationship between King Charles and Prince Harry, the Duke of Sussex, have been quashed after the King's schedule was, according to the Duke's spokesperson, too full to meet with his son.\n\nThe Duke's visit to London this week, from his home in California, for the 10th anniversary of his favorite charity, the Invictus Games for wounded military servicemen and veterans, had sparked hopes of a reunion between father and son, but a representative of the Duke said that they will not be able to meet because of \"His Majesty's full programme.\"\n\n\"The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon,\" a representative of the Duke said, The Telegraph reports.\n\nThe King has delivered \"a harsh message of rejection to Prince Harry,\" according to Tom Sykes, the royal correspondent for the Daily Beast and a longtime observer of the Windsors. Not a single senior member of the family attended a church service on Wednesday, at London's St. Paul's Cathedral, honoring the tenth anniversary of the Invictus Games, as the King was holding at the same time a palace garden party, which the senior royals - with the exception of Harry's brother, Prince William and his wife, Princess Katherine, who is being treated for cancer - were reportedly ordered to attend.\n\nThe lack of a meeting with King Charles, is \"quite a snub,\" a royal expert, Michael Cole, said per the Daily Mail.\n\n\"For the King to not see his younger son, Prince Harry, although the two men will be only two miles apart tomorrow afternoon, gives an indication of the depth of the divide,\" he said.\n\nThe King's non-meeting with Harry comes despite Charles undergoing treatments for an undisclosed form of cancer, and only recently resuming some public duties, amid reports that the cancer is serious and that the King's health is \"not good.\" At Wednesday's garden party, however, the King looked hale and happily greeted members of the public who'd been invited onto the palace grounds.\n\nThe royal snub is the latest setback for Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan Markle, the Duchess of Sussex, who for the last four years have been feuding bitterly with their family. Since January 2020, when they announced on Instagram that they are \"stepping back\" from their duties as senior royals and moving to North America, Meghan and Harry have lobbed bomb after bomb at the Windsors, in interviews, in books written by a sympathetic journalist, in documentaries and in Harry's biting bestselling memoir, \"Spare\".\n\nThe couple's face to face interactions with the other royals, necessitated by various must-attend events such as the funerals of Prince Philip and Queen Elizabeth, and Charles' coronation, have been limited and strained. On his current visit to London, Harry is not expected to see anyone from his family.\n\nThe Duke is staying at a hotel during his visit to London, having not been offered a place to stay at his family's many residences, according to GB News. According to the news outlet, he was refused a bed at Windsor Castle last September, with the palace citing \"lack of notice\" as a reason. Last year, the King asked Harry and Meghan to vacate Frogmore Cottage, their residence on the grounds of the Windsor Estate, which they'd previously been using as a place to stay during trips to England from their home in Montecito, California.\n\nPrince Harry's last trip to the UK was in February to see his father after the announcement of his cancer diagnosis. That whirlwind visit, as the Sun reported, had the royal rift on full display, as Prince Harry was only allowed to see his father for less than an hour, in the presence of his stepmother, Queen Consort Camilla, whom Harry had criticized in \"Spare\", accusing her of \"dangerous\" leaks to the media. Notably, Harry on that visit did not meet with his brother, the Prince of Wales, from whom he may be permanently estranged, according to People magazine.\n\nDuring Harry's current trip to London, Meghan is again staying home in Montecito with their two young children. The Duchess is said to be facing a \"tough\" challenge to sell her new lifestyle brand, American Riviera Orchard, to the British public.\n\nThe Duchess recently rolled out the business, which sells products meant to provide a taste of her luxurious Montecito lifestyle, by putting on the market high end jams that are supposed to reflect her sensibility and good taste. In recent weeks, she is reported to have sent jars of her new strawberry jam to celebrities including Kris Jenner, Chrissy Teigen, and Mindy Kaling in an aggressive marketing push.\n\nFor the UK rollout of American Riviera Orchard, Meghan has hired a new communications officer, according to The Telegraph. The public relations executive, The Telegraph reports, has the challenge of solving the problem of \"Meghan's appalling public image.\"\n\nThe challenge, PR expert Mark Borkowski told The Telegraph, is \"one of the most difficult jobs in PR.... second only perhaps to doing PR for Prince Andrew,\" the King's disgraced younger brother.\n\nHarry's current visit to London is expected to be a short one. He and Meghan are expected soon in Nigeria for an unofficial royal visit. As Prince Harry fronted the ceremony alone, King Charles hosted Buckingham Palace's first garden party of the season. Although the King's calendar was fully booked to set up a meeting with Prince Harry, a friend of the monarch has revealed the real reason why the father-son reunion didn't happen.\n\nA friend of King Charles told The Daily Beast that the king won't see Prince Harry due to his \"cruel\" remarks about Queen Camilla in his bombshell memoir, Spare. \"Harry has made things very difficult for himself by saying such cruel and hurtful things about Camilla,\" the friend revealed.\n\n\"Charles loves his sons, but he also loves his wife. The last few months have made it very clear how important she is; she has been the one propping up the whole edifice,\" the friend continued, adding, \"Harry has made it very clear, very publicly, that he despises her. He has forced Charles to choose, which was a very silly thing to do because Camilla and he both chose each other a long time ago.\"\n\n\"William had his reservations but he accepted his father's choice and got on with it. Harry made a different decision, and one of the inevitable consequences of publicly calling your stepmother cruel names is that it becomes difficult for you to see your father,\" the source added, per the outlet.\n\nThe King and Queen kicked off 2024's first garden party on Wednesday, May 8, the same day as Prince Harry's arrival in London. The lavish party was attended by more than 8,000 guests, including several members of the royal family. They were joined by close relatives like Anne, Princess Royal; the Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh, Prince Edward and Sophie; and the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester, Prince Richard and Birgitte.", Interestingly, the only current working royal not present was Prince William, who was busy conducting an investiture ceremony at Windsor Castle earlier in the day.\n\nCharles, who donned a grey suit and light blue waistcoat, was seen smiling at the crowds as he entered the garden with the Queen. He removed his black top hat during the national anthem and the crowds in the Buckingham Palace garden erupted into cheers as the song concluded, prompting Charles to joyfully wave his hat, reports the Mirror.\n\nOn the same day, Harry attended St Paul's Cathedral for the Invictus Games service after it was confirmed he wouldn't be seeing his father during the flying UK visit. The father-son pair last met in February when Charles announced his cancer battle and Harry rushed home from California to see him.\n\nThere were high hopes of a reunion between the somewhat estranged pair during Harry's current jaunt across the pond but a spokesperson for our favourite Royal redhead was quick to nip that in the bud. This comes after he resumed public duties last week following his cancer diagnosis earlier this year.\n\nJust last week, he expressed his 'shock' upon learning about his cancer diagnosis during a visit to a cancer centre. When asked about his health, he reassured everyone by saying: \"I'm well.\"\n\nThe King's schedule of events won't be as packed as a typical summer programme, and his attendance will be announced closer to the time and will be \"subject to doctors' advice\". It comes from a place of care towards her. You'll see that he gets red and his breathing increases.\n\n\"However, when he's on his own, he's only got himself to worry about. He's there to promote the project and sees it as a really big occasion.\"\n\nHowever, when he's on his own, he's only got himself to worry about.\n\nThe expert said Harry was the \"centre of attention at the event, which he loved\". {"uri": "8117761868", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:45:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:45:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:45:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/uk/prince-harry-makes-rare-public-appearance-appears-alone-for-uk-invictus-games-service/articleshow/109957274.cms", "title": "Prince Harry makes rare public appearance in Britain, attends UK Invictus Games service - Times of India", "body": "NEW DELHI: Prince Harry attended a service of thanksgiving in Britain on Wednesday to mark the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games. The event, held at London's St Paul's Cathedral, saw Harry, 39, make a rare public appearance in his home country. His strained relationship with his family garnered significant attention as he appeared alone at the event.\n\nThe younger son of King Charles, Harry currently resides in California with his wife Meghan and their two children.His recent memoir, interviews, and TV documentaries have contributed to his estrangement from other members of the royal family, as he openly criticized both them and the institution itself.\n\nDespite a brief reunion with his father, King Charles, following the announcement of the monarch's cancer diagnosis in February, there are no plans for the father and son to meet during Harry's latest trip to the UK. A spokesperson for Harry, the Duke of Sussex, cited the king's busy schedule as the reason for the missed opportunity, saying that Harry understands his father's commitments and priorities.\n\nWhile Harry attended the Invictus Games service at St Paul's Cathedral, King Charles hosted the first annual garden party at Buckingham Palace, accompanied by other senior royals. Additionally, the king was scheduled to carry out engagements at a military training base the following day.\n\nHarry's presence at the service marked the sole royal figure in attendance, highlighting his association with the international sporting event he founded in 2014 for wounded military personnel. He arrived at the cathedral alone, greeted by a crowd outside, and was scheduled to provide a reading during the service. Actor Damian Lewis also participated, reciting a poem to the congregation, which included veterans and wounded service personnel.\n\nFollowing his departure from Britain, Harry will be joined by Meghan for a visit to Nigeria. Meghan did not accompany Harry on his trip to London.\n\n(With agency inputs)\n\nAt TOI World Desk, our dedicated team of seasoned journalists and passionate writers tirelessly sifts through the vast tapestry of global events to bring you the latest news and diverse perspectives round the clock. Upon his arrival in London, it became known that King Charles would not be able to meet with his son, despite speculation suggesting otherwise in preceding weeks.\n\nShortly thereafter, Buckingham Palace made public that the King would bestow a military honour upon the Prince of Wales, a recognition previously assumed to be destined for the Duke of Sussex.\n\nPrince William has been appointed as the colonel-in-chief of the Army Air Corp, the regiment with which Prince Harry served during his time in Afghanistan.\n\nRoyal expert and author Tom Quinn exclusively told The Mirror: \"King Charles' announcement that Prince Harry is being stripped of his role as Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps is a real kick in the teeth for the son who always felt marginalised and underrated.\n\n\"What makes it much worse is that the role is being given to the very man who Harry sees as the cause of so many of his problems - his brother. And the announcement was deliberately made during Harry's brief visit to the UK to have maximum impact - it shows Harry that he really is no longer welcome.\"\n\nMr Quinn claimed that the senior royals \"knew\" that the announcement would \"really hurt\" Harry, before revealing that \"he is said to have been in tears when he heard\". He added: \"But they have decided the gloves are off and that Harry needs to realise that when you betray the family, you don't just escape the things you hated doing as a working royal. You also lose the things you loved.\"\n\n\"Being Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps was something Harry really did enjoy and of which he was very proud,\" Mr Quinn went on. \"There is a rushed feel to the whole thing too as if they can't wait to be rid of this troublesome prince - which is why Harry's role will be transferred to William in just a few days' time, on 13 May.", "source": Instead of attending the Service of Thanksgiving at St. Paul's Cathedral, the King was a few miles away at a garden party, as royal experts say that, had he really wanted to, Charles could have made his busy schedule work to fit in time with Harry.\n\nAs with anything, it's more complicated than it seems, apparently. Marie Claire previously reported that the last time Harry was in the U.K. -- back in February, when he flew to London to see his father within hours of the King announcing he had been diagnosed with cancer on February 5 -- it was Queen Camilla, Harry's stepmother, who kept the visit so short while at Clarence House. Despite flying approximately 11,000 miles roundtrip from Los Angeles to London and back, Harry only spent about 30 minutes with his father at Charles and Camilla's home in London, as Charles had just started cancer treatment the day before.\n\n\"The Queen was with the King,\" royal biographer Robert Jobson said, per The Sun. \"Let's be honest -- he [Harry] wasn't too complimentary about Queen Camilla in his book, Spare. He wasn't very complimentary about her on Netflix [in his Harry & Meghan docuseries]. They don't get on.\" Jobson added, \"Second, there's not been a lot of contact. That brings its own level of complexity and drama which he [the King] doesn't need at the moment.\" The King \"gave him [Harry] long enough for a kiss and a hug and wished him all the best,\" Jobson said.\n\nThis week marks Harry's first time back in the U.K. since that quick trip in early February, and royal expert Charlotte Griffiths said on GB News that Charles' refusal to meet up with Harry was decided after Harry apparently made \"certain demands\" that couldn't be met, The Mirror reports. These \"difficult\" negotiations seem to surround who could be in the room for the father and son meeting -- namely Camilla, who Charles wanted in the room but Harry did not. \"We know that Charles likes to meet Harry with Camilla in the room, which isn't always a popular decision,\" Griffiths said. \"Harry was without his wife as well, so this was fraught with difficulty.\" (Meghan Markle isn't in the U.K. with Harry, but will meet up with him in Nigeria later on.)\n\nGriffiths also suggested on GB News that \"other forces\" may have driven Charles' decision about meeting up with Harry, including -- you guessed it -- Prince William. \"William may have had a thought about how this meeting should be conducted or whether it should be conducted at all,\" she said.\n\nA source told Russell Myers, royal editor of The Mirror, that when it comes to William and Harry, \"Their relationship remains extremely fractured,\" they said. \"Harry has privately expressed a wish to sit down with his brother, but now is not the time.\" It should be noted that this is Harry's first visit back to his home country since his sister-in-law, the Princess of Wales, announced publicly on March 22 that she too had been diagnosed with cancer; there are apparently no plans for the two, once so close, to meet.\n\nEarlier today, Harry was leaving an event in Central London and was headed for his car when a waiting cameraman asked him \"Are you happy to be home?\" Because of all of the above and so much more, it was about as loaded a question as it gets, and Harry's response is telling: per arrived at St. Paul's Cathedral for a service honoring his Invictus Games tournament for veterans after acknowledging he will not see his father, King Charles III during his trip to the United Kingdom.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex was booed the last time he attended St. Paul's in June 2022 for a service honoring Queen Elizabeth II's Platinum Jubilee alongside Meghan Markle.\n\nHowever, he did not let that experience put him off as he entered the historic London cathedral on Wednesday for a special service marking 10 years of his tournament for injured veterans.\n\nActor Damien Lewis, who starred in Homeland, will recite a poem at the service and Harry is expected to give a reading.\n\nThere was widespread speculation in the British media that Charles and Harry would see each other due to them being a few miles apart from one another, particularly in light of the fact the king is still undergoing treatment for cancer.\n\nHowever, the Sussex team revealed that Charles had not found time for Harry owing to his packed schedule and \"various other priorities.\"\n\nKing Charles had a meeting with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak in his diary on Wednesday and hosted a garden party at Buckingham Palace in the afternoon.\n\nA spokesperson for Harry said on Tuesday: \"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme.\n\n\"The duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nOn Tuesday night, Prince Harry swerved a question from a journalist who asked him, \"Harry, are you happy to be home?\" as he climbed into a car.\n\nThe duke simply replied, \"Hello, hi,\" and laughed awkwardly.\n\nJack Royston is Newsweek's chief royal correspondent based in London. {"uri": "8119607427", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:14:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:14:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:13:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/life/prince-harry-is-in-london-but-the-king-is-too-busy-to-see-him-really/article_ccca6bfa-0e1c-11ef-aa11-ef4321e98fa2.html", "title": "Sarah Laing: Prince Harry is in London, but the King is too busy to see him. Really?", "body": "Father and son haven't seen each other in three months, but the prince's spokesperson says \"His Majesty's full program\" is keeping them apart.\n\nPrince Harry is back in London -- and, predictable as Big Ben tolling the hour, Royal Family drama has followed in his black Range Rover's wake.\n\nDid King Charles snub his son by refusing to see him? Is Harry manipulating the facts purely to make his family look bad, knowing they'll never exercise their public right of reply? And where on Earth is Meghan Markle?!\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThat last bit of the tittle-tattle kerfuffle is the easiest to answer: Meghan Markle is still in California, although she'll be joining Harry later this week in Nigeria, where the government has invited them on a series of private visits related to how the African country is using sport to aid their military with physical and emotional recovery. (This is in connection to the couple's work with Harry's Invictus Games and not, say, the \"pseudo royal tour\" their detractors have accused them of embarking on.)\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAs for the rest of it, however, Harry's 48 hours in his home country have seemingly stirred up the waters of royal rancour once more, bringing the family's private chasm firmly back into the public conversation.\n\nWhether any of this is Harry's doing, of course, is up for debate. On one hand, he's in the U.K. in a capacity entirely unrelated to his family, attending a celebration marking 10 years of the Invictus Games, a charity he founded off the back of his own experiences as a soldier in his pre-working royal youth. (Yes, the founding money came from the Royal Foundation and the U.K. Defense Ministry, but the star power and clear commitment to his fellow veterans that have made this thing a success, even 10 years later, has to be credited to Harry.)\n\nOn the flip side, it was his spokesperson who took the speculation around whether Harry would meet with his father while in the country and put it into the official record.\n\n\"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the Duke will meet with his father while in the U.K. this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full program,\" the Sussex spokesperson said. \"The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nDid Harry really need to publicly address this? Could it not have been left as a private matter between family members, and the speculators left to wonder until they're blue in the face? It's hard to take this statement -- and the gracious light in which it seeks to paint Harry, the olive-branch-extending son rebuffed by his cold, work-obsessed father -- as anything other than point-scoring and hornets-nest poking.\n\nEqually, it could just be a bit of proactive, protective PR, a move to shut down all the speculation about this family, try to shift some of the focus onto the Invictus Games and head off the inevitable accusations of how dreadful, what an utter ingrate, he is when it emerges that he did not see his dad while he was in London.\n\nSimilarly, you could see his mention of his father's dedication to his duty as King, newly back in front of the public after being sidelined by cancer treatment, as an attempt to recast what seems to be Charles's very deliberate snub of his son in a kinder light.\n\nDoes the fact that Harry announced, on stage at an Invictus event on Tuesday, that he was having dinner with an old friend that evening have anything to do with this? Well, per some quarters, it was a desperate attempt to make sure nobody pictured him alone and pathetic in his hotel room, a man who'd been so terrible to his family that they couldn't even stomach dinner with him. Or, maybe, the friend in question was involved in the Invictus Games and the remark made sense in the context of the conversation.\n\nAnd then, a fourth data point equally open to interpretation: On the eve of Harry's visit, the palace announced a father-son engagement for Charles and William next week, a symbolic handing over of an honourary military title.\n\nBut wait, the plot thickened yesterday! The producers of The Crown couldn't have scripted it any better: At St Paul's Cathedral, we had Prince Harry, who arrived to cheering crowds outside the abbey where his parents were married, spotted warmly greeting his mother's brother and sister.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nWhile, just a few miles away at Buckingham Palace, we had the first garden party of the year, the King and Queen Camilla surrounded by most of the working royals -- like Princess Anne, fresh of a plane from a trip to British Columbia; Edward and Sophie; B-tier cousins the Gloucesters -- chatting to members of the public in the bright spring sunshine like there was nowhere they'd rather be.\n\nWhen you cut from one to the other, fascinating details emerge. There's Harry, for example, seen sporting his military medals, something that has been interpreted as a dig at his dad, who denied him the right to wear his military uniform to the coronation. Or, he's a military vet at a military event!\n\nThe strong showing from his mother's family can also be seen two ways: There's the crowd on the internet hailing them as Harry's \"true family,\" harking back to the blistering eulogy that his uncle gave at Diana's funeral, seeming to call out the royals for the way they treated her, and pledging to look after her sons on her behalf. Alternately, the Spencers and Harry arguably occupy similar places in the royal periphery now, benefitting from the attention their proximity to the Windsors gives them. See: Harry's uncle Charles Spencer, whose recent (very moving, very tough to read) memoir was widely publicized as \"Princess Diana's brother's book.\" Not his fault, necessarily, but it certainly didn't hurt. As, likewise, popping up into the public conscience as the family members who stood by Harry when even his own brother or father couldn't be bothered to come out and support him.\n\nThe other end of the narrative spectrum on this is that Charles has very deliberately made a public show of snubbing Harry, and has no problem if the world thinks that he is being unnecessarily cruel to his son.\n\n\"'He doesn't need the drama in his life,\" a \"friend\" of the King and queen told the Daily Mail. \"Harry and Meghan have brought him, and the rest of the family, nothing but worries over the past few years.\" Another of these pals told the tabloid, \"Frankly speaking, Harry and Meghan are a painful distraction that he could do without.\" (If it wasn't clear whose side the Mail is on, simply consider their body language analysis of the day: The King was \"delighted\" and \"playful\" while Harry -- despite the big smile on his face -- was apparently \"wary\" and filled with an \"inner anxiety\" that he gave away by doing up the button on his suit jacket.)\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nElsewhere in the realm of unnamed sources, the Daily Beast is claiming that Charles specifically ordered all of those senior royals to the garden party, ensuring that Harry looked like a loner. Or maybe he did it to save those other family members from being forced to choose?\n\nEither way, the truth in all of this is as murky as it's ever been -- and the family drama ever juicier...and sadder, really.", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Star"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sarah_laing@thestar.com", "name": "Sarah Laing", "type": "author", "isAgency": "body": "PRINCE Harry has arrived at a glitzy Invictus bash just three miles from his dad King Charles's garden party.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex has jetted from California for a service at St Paul's Cathedral to mark the 10th anniversary of his Invictus Games.\n\nThe Prince wore an all-black suit with a matching tie and a crisp white shirt.\n\nOn the left side of his blazer, Harry proudly hung his military medals.\n\nSitting down in St Paul's, the Duke of Sussex hugged Charles Spencer - Princess Diana's brother - and lady Jane fellowes who are sat behind him.\n\nHarry will leave the service at around 6pm - just as Charles wraps up the first Buckingham Palace garden party of the year.\n\nA spokesperson for Harry said the prince will not meet Charles on his whistle-stop UK tour - because the King is too busy.\n\nCharles, 75, resumed public duties last week for the first time since beginning cancer treatment.\n\nHarry's spokesperson said: \"It unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme.\n\n\"The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nIn a second snub, Charles revealed Prince William will take charge of Harry's former helicopter regiment next week.\n\nNext week Charles will confirm William as Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps.\n\nThe event will take place in front of an Apache -- the type of helicopter Harry flew when serving in Afghanistan.\n\nWilliam, who flew with the Air Ambulance, will also take to the skies in the chopper.\n\nHarry passed his Army Air Corps grading and Pilot's Selection Board interview in December 2008 to begin pilot training in January 2009.\n\nOn his first tour of Afghanistan in 2008 he called in air strikes on Taliban positions.\n\nHe later qualified as an Apache commander in 2012 after three years of training.\n\nThen he spent a five-month tour in Afghanistan where he piloted an Apache.\n\nA source told The Sun: \"Timing is everything.\"\n\nInsiders claim Harry made multiple attempts to arrange a meeting with his dad before flying 5,000 miles for three days in the UK.\n\nHarry flew to the UK alone
