Harry was in London Wednesday to mark the 10th anniversary of his Invictus Games for wounded military veterans, but no meeting was scheduled with his estranged father King Charles III.\n\nAs with all his trips to the UK since he moved to the United States in 2020, his three-day visit to the British capital has sparked a fresh round of speculation about a reconciliation with his family.\n\nA possible end to four years of rancour and score-settling was seen as on the cards in February, when Harry jetted in from California to briefly see his father after it was announced that he had cancer.\n\nBut the palace doors look firmly shut to him this time round.\n\nA spokesman for the Duke of Sussex, as Harry is also known, said on Wednesday that a meeting this week \"will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme\".\n\n\"The duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon,\" he added.\n\nThe king's \"diary of commitments\" has been less full than usual in recent months, as Charles, 75, receives chemotherapy for cancer.\n\nBut it is filling up again after doctors said they were \"very encouraged\" by the progress of his treatment, allowing him to ease back into official public engagements.\n\nOn Tuesday, the king was pictured meeting Fiji's Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka at Buckingham Palace, as Harry attended a discussion on the Invictus Games in London's financial district.\n\nOn Wednesday, the British head of state attended the first garden party of the year at Buckingham Palace, while Harry was just under three miles (five kilometres) away at St Paul's Cathedral.\n\nThe majestic dome of St Paul's was where Charles married Harry's mother, Princess Diana, in 1981.\n\nOutside the church, one onlooker told AFP the king was \"quite right\" not to agree to meet, suggesting Harry was on a publicity trip and acting as if he was still a working royal.\n\n\"I think they're quite right to say, 'no meeting'. Can't have it both ways,\" they said.\n\nBut one woman, who gave her name as Tracy, said she was a fan and suggested public opinion was being manipulated by the media against Harry.\n\n\"At the end of the day, we don't know if there's any truth in what they've been saying. But if there's any truth in it, I think it's sad,\" she said.\n\n- 'Regal middle finger' -\n\nThe lack of meeting -- even for a short time -- has been interpreted as a snub for Harry, compounded by an Corps in Afghanistan.\n\nNo meeting is planned either with William, who is due on a visit to Cornwall in southwest England, and the Isles of Scilly on Thursday and Friday.\n\nWilliam's wife Catherine is also undergoing cancer treatment and has not made any public appearance since December last year.\n\nThe brothers, once close, are reportedly no longer on speaking terms due to Harry's criticisms Photos from the event showed Harry with a big smile as he waved at the crowds. He looked dapper in a navy blue suit adorned with medals.\n\nHello Magazine's royal reporters attended the service on Wednesday, and shared that royal watchers were \"eager\" to see the prince's prodigal return. Following Harry's reading within the church, actor Damian Lewis recited the poem, \"Invictus\" by William Ernest Henley.\n\nHarry cofounded the Invictus Games in 2014. Wounded, injured and sick military personnel compete in multiple sports at the event. The most recent Invictus Games were held in Germany in September 2023.\n\nFollowing the anniversary celebration, Harry is set to travel to Nigeria with wife Meghan Markle. The couple, who tied the knot in May 2018 and are parents of son Archie, 5, and daughter Lilibet, 2, were invited by Nigeria's chief of defense staff in an effort to highlight the Invictus Games. \"The visit is to consolidate Nigeria's strong hold at the game and the possibility of hosting the event in later years,\" according to Brigadier General Tukur Gusau, Nigeria's acting director of defense information.\n\nAhead of Harry's trip to London, royal watchers wondered whether he would reunite with his father, King Charles III, who is battling cancer.\n\n\"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the duke will meet with his father while in the U.K. this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full program,\" Harry's spokesperson told Us Weekly in a statement on Tuesday, May 7.\n\nAfter Buckingham Palace confirmed Charles' diagnosis in February, Harry rushed to the U.K. to be by his father's side, though their visit lasted less than an hour.\n\n\"I jumped on a plane and went to go see him as soon as I could,\" Harry explained to Good Morning America at the time. \"I love my family. The fact that I was able to get on a plane and go and see him and spend any time with him, I'm grateful for that.\"\n\nIn February, Buckingham Palace announced that Charles, 75, had \"commenced a schedule of regular treatments\" for cancer, during which time he had been \"advised by doctors to postpone public-facing duties.\"\n\nCharles resumed his responsibilities in April with a visit to a specialist cancer center in London. {"uri": "8119214546", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:24:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:24:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:24:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/entertainment/celebrity/prince-harry-in-tears-king-32771968", "title": "Harry 'in tears' as Charles 'strips him of role' and hands it to William", "body": "A Royal expert claims Prince Harry was \"in tears\" when King Charles announced a new honour for Prince William.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex returned to the UK this week for the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games. Shortly after arriving in London, it was revealed that King Charles was too busy to meet with his son, despite weeks of speculation that they could be meeting.\n\nJust hours after it was confirmed that King Charles would not be meeting with Prince Harry, Buckingham Palace announced that the King would hand the Prince of Wales a military honour long thought to be destined for the Duke of Sussex.\n\nPrince William is now colonel-in-chief of the Army Air Corp - the regiment Prince Harry served with in Afghanistan.\n\nRoyal commentator Tom Quinn spoke to the Mirror, revealing: \"King Charles' announcement that Prince Harry is being stripped of his role as Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps is a real kick in the teeth for the son who always felt marginalised and underrated.\n\n\"What makes it much worse is that the role is being given to the very man who Harry sees as the cause of so many of his problems his brother. And the announcement was deliberately made during Harry's brief visit to the UK to have maximum impact it shows Harry that he really is no longer welcome.\"\n\nQuinn disclosed that the Royal family \"knew\" the timing of the announcement would \"really hurt\" Harry, and shared that \"he is said to have been in tears when he heard\".\n\nJoin the Daily Record's WhatsApp community here and get the latest news sent straight to your messages.\n\nHe continued: \"But they have decided the gloves are off and that Harry needs to realise that when you betray the family, you don't just escape the things you hated doing as a working royal. You also lose the things you loved.\"\n\n\"Being Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps was something Harry really did enjoy and of which he was very proud,\" added Quinn. \"There is a rushed feel to the whole thing too as if they can't wait to be rid of this troublesome prince which is why Harry's role will be transferred to William in just a few days' time, on 13 May.\"\n\nQuinn also mentioned: \"Harry feels his time in the military was a rare happy time in his life when he was judged on his merits as a man not on his merits as a member of the Royal Family.\"\n\nWrapping up his thoughts, Mr Quinn stated: \"Having always hated being the spare in terms of the succession he now finds that one of the few important roles he had as the younger brother has now been handed over to the person Harry himself described as his nemesis. {"uri": "2024-05-349470238", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "20:21:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T20:21:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T20:16:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/harry-arrives-st-pauls-during-161255435.html", "title": "Harry and King at London events but will not meet", "body": "Sean Coughlan - Royal correspondent, at St Paul's Cathedral and Sean Seddon - BBC News\n\nThe Duke of Sussex has attended a service at St Paul's Cathedral in London during a brief visit to the UK.\n\nPrince Harry was speaking at the event to mark the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games, the sporting competition for injured service men and women he helped found.\n\nMeanwhile, the King, whose cancer treatment is ongoing, met members of the public at a Buckingham Palace garden party a little over two miles away.\n\nThe two are not scheduled to see each other while both are in London.\n\nThe duke's spokesman said the King's \"full programme\" prevented any meeting.\n\nA crowd gathered in the sunshine outside St Paul's to greet Prince Harry, the driving force behind the Invictus Games, who smiled and waved from the steps as he arrived.\n\nOnce inside, he gave a warm greeting to his uncle, Earl Spencer, who was sitting behind him in the cathedral.\n\nSpeaking in the church where his parents were married, Prince Harry gave a Bible reading from Corinthians that emphasised different people have different gifts and strengths.\n\nAnother reading from Isaiah talked of stopping \"the pointing of the finger, the speaking of evil\".\n\nThere was also an emotional reading of a poem about the positive impact of the Invictus Games by Michelle Turner, captain of the UK's team in Sydney in 2018.\n\nThis was clearly a very personal event for Prince Harry. With the tight-knit Invictus congregation seated in a circle, under the cathedral dome, it was almost literally his circle of trust.\n\nWith the traditional hymns and prayers, the ranks of clergy, and no gimmicks or modern twists, you could imagine his grandmother the late Queen Elizabeth II fitting in comfortably with such a service.\n\nWith the mellow late afternoon sunshine coming in through the long windows, it was a surprisingly intimate celebration of a decade of helping to give a sense of purpose to individuals and families under pressure.\n\nIt was also shaped like a royal event, complete with cameras and cheers outside and Prince Harry shaking a few excited hands as he was leaving.\n\nThere was plenty of support for him in this instant crowd of passers-by and tourists.\n\nHe has been in legal battles over security during visits to the UK, but there were lines of City of London police here seeing him safely away.\n\nHowever, there was also an inescapable sense of absence, with none of his royal relations there with him.\n\nThe headlines have become about who wasn't there, including his father and brother.\n\nThis felt very much like a solo mission.\n\nThe duke, who now lives in California, last saw the King in person shortly after his February announcement that he was being treated for an unspecified form of cancer.\n\nThe King has since returned to some public duties but is continuing to receive medical care.\n\nOn Wednesday he was seen removing his top hat and waving it in the air as a crowd greeted him by singing the national anthem at Buckingham Palace.\n\nPrince Harry is also not expected to meet the Prince or Princess of Wales - who is also being treated for cancer - while in the UK.\n\nOn Tuesday, a spokesperson for the duke said: \"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme.\n\n\"The duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nOn Tuesday, the duke attended an Invictus Games summit in London, where he told delegates: \"Sometimes you... look back and go 'Look at what we've done'.\n\n\"But also given the state of the world, there is so much more to do and I think a lot of uncertainty - but what we've created is a global community.\"\n\nPrince Harry is not being joined by the Duchess of Sussex for this visit, but his wife is scheduled to meet him in Nigeria, where he is due to travel after his stop in London.\n\nThe couple were invited by Nigeria's chief of defence staff after they met at the Invictus Games held last year in Germany.\n\nSign up here to get the latest royal stories and analysis straight to your inbox every week with our Royal Watch newsletter. {"uri": "8119022161", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:17:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:17:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:17:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/royals/article-13399137/Prince-Harry-UK-Megxit-Queen-funeral-Coronation.html", "title": "How Prince Harry has been back to UK a handful of times since 'Megxit'", "body": "Prince Harry has been all smiles this week on his return to the UK to mark the tenth anniversary of the Invictus Games - even if his father the King is too busy to see him.\n\nIt comes more than four years after his and Meghan's final royal engagement before 'Megxit' - a very awkward appearance alongside Prince William and Kate at the Commonwealth Day service in 2020.\n\nSince moving to sunny California, Harry has been back only a handful of times - and usually without his wife, the Duchess of Sussex.\n\nThe Duke first returned for Prince Philip's funeral in April 2021, before coming again that summer when he and his brother put their differences aside to unveil a statue of his late mother Princess Diana.\n\nHe and Meghan then made a secret visit to see Queen Elizabeth II and Charles at Windsor in April 2022, before the couple returned again for Her Late Majesty's Platinum Jubilee in June.\n\nThere were was another solo visit for the King's Coronation last year, before Harry very briefly returned again to see his father following his cancer diagnosis.\n\nPrince Harry arrives at the Invictus Games Foundation's anniversary celebrations at St Paul's Cathedral yesterday\n\nThe strain of Megxit was crystal clear at Harry and Meghan's final public engagement at the Commonwealth Day Service inside Westminster Abbey in 2020. Above: Harry and Meghan at the service behind Prince William and Kate and Charles, then the Prince of Wales\n\nThe funeral of Prince Phillip - April 2021\n\nPrince Harry made the ten-hour flight to Britain for the funeral of his grandfather Prince Phillip in April 2021.\n\nSpeaking in his and Meghan's bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey, Harry said he was 'worried' and 'afraid' to return to the UK amid tensions between him and Meghan and his family but that he was able to work through any trepidation using coping skills learned in therapy.\n\n'It definitely made it a lot easier, but the heart still pounds,' said the Duke of Sussex.\n\nPrince Harry joined Prince William, Peter Phillips, David Armstrong-Jones and Vice-Admiral Sir Timothy Laurence behind the Land Rover Defender hearse which carried the Duke of Edinburgh's coffin during the Ceremonial Procession.\n\nHis contact with the Queen was limited due to the Covid-19 pandemic.\n\nIt is understood that Harry was anxious to return to America to be with Meghan, who was seven months pregnant with their daughter Lilibet at the time.\n\nPrince Harry admitted he was nervous to return to the UK amid tensions between him, Meghan and his family. Above: Harry with Prince William, Peter Phillips, David Armstrong-Jones and Vice Admiral Sir Timothy Laurence at during Prince Philip's funeral procession\n\nPrince Harry joined his father King Charles (then the Prince of Wales), Prince William, Peter Phillips, David Armstrong-Jones and Vice-Admiral Sir Timothy Laurence behind the Land Rover Defender hearse which carried the Duke of Edinburgh's coffin during the Ceremonial Procession\n\nUnveiling of Princess Diana statue - July 2021\n\nHarry and William briefly set aside their differences to reveal a statue of their late mother Diana, Princess of Wales, on what would have been her 60th birthday.\n\nThe brothers smiled as they pulled the green cover to reveal the bronze sculpture in the remodelled Sunken Garden at Kensington Palace.\n\nCharles was not present at the ceremony, which was changed to a 'private event' instead of the large celebration to mark Diana's life as originally intended.\n\nThe move to scale back the unveiling was largely due to bad blood between the brothers.\n\nIt was only broadcast after the reveal was over and the Duke of Sussex was leaving.\n\nThe brothers smiled as they pulled the green cover to reveal the bronze sculpture of their mother\n\nPrince Harry and Prince William stood shoulder to shoulder during the unveiling of the statue on what would have been her 60th birthday\n\nThe brothers set their differences aside to attend the ceremony in the Sunken Garden at Kensington Palace\n\nHarry was seen talking to his uncle Earl Spencer at the unveiling of the statue\n\nSecret talks with the Queen and Charles - April 2022\n\nHarry and Meghan visited Britain en route to the Invictus Games in Holland - marking the first time the Duchess set foot on British soil since Megxit.\n\nThey arrived incognito and stayed overnight with Princess Eugenie and her family at Frogmore Cottage, the home they kept on despite quitting the UK.\n\nAlthough they attempted to keep their visit top secret, the couple were spotted walking to Windsor Castle by churchgoers arriving for the Royal Maundy Service.\n\nIt is believed there were heading to the Queen's official residence to see the monarch as well as Harry's father, Charles.\n\nIn April 2022, Harry and Meghan made a low-key visit to see the Queen and Charles at Windsor Castle. Above: The couple on the Buckingham Palace balcony with the Queen in 2018\n\nThe Platinum Jubilee - June 2022\n\nDuring a lunch behind closed doors as part of the Platinum Jubilee celebrations, the Queen reportedly met her great-granddaughter Lilibet for the first time.\n\nRoyal commentator Omid Scoobie - widely seen as a cheerleader for Harry and Meghan - told BBC Breakfast at the time: 'Those moments with Lilibet are very much private between them and the Queen and of course we know how much she's been looking forward to it.\n\n'They've been held back by a pandemic. Of course the times that Harry has been here it's just been by himself for quite sombre occasions. And so this really was the first time.\n\nLilibet celebrated her first birthday the following day, and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex released a photo of her to mark the occasion.\n\nMeghan, Duchess of Sussex and Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex attending the National Service of Thanksgiving to celebrate the Platinum Jubilee\n\nDuring a lunch behind closed doors as part of the Platinum Jubilee celebrations, the Queen reportedly met her great-granddaughter Lilibet for the first time. Above: Harry and Meghan attending the National Service of Thanksgiving to celebrate the Queen's Platinum Jubilee\n\nThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex released a photo of Lilibet to mark her first birthday in June 2022\n\nQueen's death and funeral - September 2022\n\nHarry and Meghan were in London for the WellChild Awards Ceremony when the Queen's health deteriorated at her beloved Scottish home.\n\nBut Harry flew via private jet alone, arriving to Balmoral shortly after the Queen's death was announced to the public.\n\nIn his explosive biography Spare, Harry claimed that his father instructed him not to bring his wife Meghan to visit the dying Queen Elizabeth II, citing 'nonsensical and disrespectful' reasons.\n\nEnraged by Charles' perceived snub, Harry allegedly retorted: 'Don't ever speak about my wife that way!', prompting the King to offer an apology.\n\nThe couple later attended the Queen's funeral in Westminster Abbey without their children.\n\nHarry returning to Windsor following the death of the Queen, September 9, 2022\n\nCatherine, Princess of Wales, Prince William, Prince of Wales, Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex meet members of the public on the long Walk at Windsor Castle after the Queen's death\n\nIn his explosive biography Spare, Harry wrote that his father instructed him not to bring his wife Meghan to visit the dying Queen Elizabeth II. Above: The Prince and Princess of Wales and Harry and Meghan walk together down the Long Walk at Windsor Castle after the Queen's death\n\nThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex attended the Queen's funeral in Westminster Abbey, where Meghan appeared to cry for the late monarch\n\nCoronation of King Charles - May 2023\n\nAt the King's Coronation, Harry sat two rows behind his brother at Westminster Abbey.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex was not invited to appear on the balcony following the ceremony.\n\nInstead he hopped on a plane back to America just hours after his father was crowned, eager to get back for his son's birthday celebrations.\n\nA well-placed source said The King seemed 'genuinely quite disappointed that he didn't stay'.\n\nThe monarch even raised a glass to toast Archie on his fourth birthday - a grandson he has barely seen.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex attended the King's Coronation at Westminster Abbey but was not invited to appear on the balcony following the ceremony\n\nPrince Harry arrived with Princess Beatrice and her husband Edoardo Mapelli Mozzi who put an arm around him before the ceremony\n\nVisit to see King after cancer diagnosis - February 2024\n\nPrince Harry made a months.\n\nLeading Royal expert Robert Jobson suggested the meeting was not any longer to stop the monarch from experiencing unnecessary stress.\n\nPrince Harry arrives in the UK to see his father Invictus Games", "body": "The Duke of Sussex has celebrated the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games with a service of thanksgiving at St Paul's Cathedral.\n\nHarry joined a congregation of around 1,000 people inside the London landmark where he gave a bible reading.\n\nUnlike the launch of the Games in 2014, now King Charles and Queen Camilla and Prince William were not in attendance.\n\nAmong the guests were the siblings of Harry's mother, Diana, Princess of Wales - Lady Jane Fellowes and Earl Spencer.\n\nThe wife of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, Akshata Murty, and Minister for Veterans' Affairs Johnny Mercer also attended the event.\n\nHarry spent some time before the service catching up with his aunt and uncle.\n\nThe service reflected on the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games, which the Duke set up to stage sporting events for wounded, sick or injured veterans to aid their recovery.\n\nHe was inspired to found the global tournament after attending the Warrior Games in Colorado in 2013 and seeing how injured American military personnel thrived on the challenge of taking part in competitive sports that aided their recovery.\n\nMrs Turner, Team UK captain for the 2018 Games, told the guests: \"Wounded, injured, sick, and now with no career: consumed by insecurities, the pain and the fear.\n\n\"Our lives were upside down, how could it be, that the little girl I was meant to protect, was now looking after me.\"\n\nAt the end, after her voice broke with emotion as she said: \"Thank you Invictus for giving my life back\", after which the congregation stood and applauded.\n\nThe Dean of St Paul's echoed her words in his sermon when he said the Invictus Games Foundation, which organises the competition, was \"not only changing lives through sport but quite literally by saving lives\".\n\nHarry later joined some of the Invictus community for a private reception in the cathedral's crypt and it is thought he will travel on Thursday to Nigeria, for a tour {"uri": "8118313120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "01:55:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T01:55:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T01:54:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/royals/signs-prince-harry-major-transformation-32767357", "title": "Bold signs previously 'restricted, closed off' Harry has had big transformation", "body": "Prince Harry is displaying bold signs on his long-awaited visit back to the UK that the previously \"restricted and closed off\" Duke has undergone a major transformation.\n\nA body language expert has taken a good look at the estranged Prince's swagger during his somewhat fraught solo trip to Blighty and has revealed Harry appears to have blossomed, becoming \"his most confident self\" and feeling \"very positive and proud about where he is right now\".\n\nThe Duke of Sussex, who it was announced will not reunite with his father, King Charles, during his visit, and is thought highly unlikely to meet with his brother Prince William and sister-in-Law Kate Middleton. He is sadly believed to be in the midst of an unresolved royal rift with his family.\n\nREAD MORE: William and Kate's 'frightening fight' means they won't 'deal with Harry Problem'\n\nPrince Harry appeared to have grown in confidence, according to one body language expert\n\nDarren Stanton, a body language expert with Betfair Slots, has revealed that Harry is clearly in \"very high spirits\" during his solo trip to the UK, despite being supposedly \"snubbed\" by his father. Harry, who has a busy schedule of activities lined up, was spotted at Armoury House in London on Tuesday, May 7, for an Invictus Games discussion titled 'Realising a Global Community'. This marks his first appearance since arriving in the UK.\n\nPrince Harry appears to be in 'very high spirits' during his trip to the UK\n\nThe prince flew in from his home in Montecito, California, to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the Invictus Games. However, it's been revealed that he won't be meeting with his father due to clashing schedules. Despite missing out on a reunion, the Duke doesn't seem to be showing any signs of disappointment. In fact, Darren suggests that Harry is feeling \"positive and proud.\"\n\nHarry even engaged with Pikemen and Musketeers\n\nDarren told OK!: \"Harry appears to be his most confident self during his return to the UK as he prepares for the Invictus Games. His body language suggests he's feeling strong, as we can't see him using self-reassurance gestures - which he often uses when feeling nervous. He is seen holding his head up high, with his shoulders back and displaying a bold grin. He's developed a lot in terms of his inner strength and confidence. It tells us he is feeling very positive and proud about where he is right now. He is in very high spirits.\"\n\nHarry was previously 'restricted and closed off'\n\nAs the Invictus Games, an organisation dear to Prince Harry, takes centre stage, Darren said the Prince is clearly offering his \"full attention and engagement\" to everyone he interacts with, indicating his boosted confidence. Harry's consistent use of eye contact and assertive gestures make him appear \"open and welcoming\", as opposed to \"restricted and closed off\", which has been the case in the past. \"He feels comfortable and at ease,\" Darren added.\n\nWhile Harry has so far travelled to the UK solo, his wife Meghan Markle is set to join him later in the week for a pre-scheduled trip to Nigeria. Charles apparently ordered all working royals to attend a 5,000-person garden party at Buckingham Palace because nothing screams \"fun\" like a mandatory party. Diana's family...", "body": "Prince Harry was thrilled to be reunited with members of Princess Diana's family at the Invictus Games celebrations -- after being shunned by his father and brother, sources tell Page Six.\n\nHarry, 39, warmly hugged his uncle, Earl Spencer, and aunt, Lady Jane Fellowes, both of whom attended the event on Wednesday to celebrate 10 years of the charity that the renegade royal founded.\n\nKing Charles and Prince William may have no time for Harry after he trashed them in his bombshell memoir \"Spare\" -- but his mother's family is more than making up for it.\n\nA source told us, \"You can see how sweet they were together.\"\n\nDespite the fact that Charles would not see Harry while he was in London, the source stressed that he is still hopeful for a reunion, adding, \"Family is important to Harry -- period, regardless of what side of the family.\"\n\nIn addition to his aunt and uncle, Harry's cousins Lara Spencer, Louis Spencer, and George McCorquodale, were also spotted entering the event at St Paul's Cathedral.\n\nDiana's family members then joined Harry at a reception after the service, attended by \"Homeland\" actor Damien Lewis, held in the Crypt at St Paul's, we're told.\n\nLess than three miles away, Charles hosted the first Garden Party of the year at Buckingham Palace.\n\nHe was joined by a slew of senior working royals, including Queen Camilla, Princess Anne, Prince Edward, and Sophie, Duchess of Edinburgh.\n\nHarry's rep told us earlier this week that Charles, who is currently battling cancer, was too busy to see his youngest son.\n\nWe revealed that Harry had been trying to reach his father for the past month, to no avail. Sources denied that he had made any bizarre requests ahead of seeing Charles, calling it \"rubbish\".\n\nHarry has been open about the toll that losing his mother at such a young age took on him.\n\nIn his 2023 Netflix docuseries, \"Heart of Invictus\", Harry revealed, \"My tour of Afghanistan in 2012, flying Apaches, somewhere after that there was an unraveling and the trigger to me was actually returning from Afghanistan.\n\n\"But the stuff that was coming up was from 1997 from the age of 12, losing my mum at such a young age, the trauma that I had I was never really aware of, it was never discussed.\"\n\nHe continued, \"It was never discussed, I didn't really talk about it and I suppressed it like most youngsters would have done.\n\n\"But when it all came fizzing out, I was bouncing off the walls. I was like, 'What is going on here? I'm now feeling everything as opposed to being numb.'\n\n\"The biggest struggle for me was no-one around me really could help.\"\n\nEarl Spencer famously revealed the harsh divide between the Spencers and the royal family at Diana's funeral in September 1997 when he said that Diana's siblings would watch over Harry and William.\n\n\"I pledge that we, your blood family, will do all we can to continue the imaginative way in which you were steering these two exceptional young men so that their souls are not simply immersed by duty and tradition but can sing openly as you planned,\" he said.\n\n\"We fully respect the heritage into which they have both been born and will always respect and encourage them in their royal role but we, like you, recognize the need for them to experience as many different aspects of life as possible to arm them spiritually and emotionally for the years ahead.\n\n\"I know you would have expected nothing less from us.\"\n\nAnd Harry has remained close with the Spencer side of his family, despite moving to the US.\n\nDiana's sisters, Lady Jane and Lady Sarah McCorquodale, were photographed alongside Charles and Camilla, William and Kate Middleton at Prince Archie's christening in July 2019.\n\nThey were also believed to be in attendance at Princess Lilibet's christening in Montecito in May 2023.\n\nHarry and his wife Meghan Markle visited Althorp, Diana's childhood home, in September 2022 -- while they were in the UK following the death of Queen Elizabeth II.\n\nThere they spent time with his uncle and his aunts, and visited Diana's final resting place, which lies on an island at the estate.\n\nMeanwhile, Harry was also joined by a host of old friends at the Invictus event, including former army officer Mark Dyer, who has been a mentor to the Duke.\n\nThe fifth in line to the throne has not been in the UK since February when he met with Charles for barely 30 minutes following the monarch's cancer diagnosis. people experiencing homelessness in the area.\n\nIn partnership with the Cornish homelessness charity St Petrocs, the homes in Nansledan will come with \"wraparound support\".\n\nThis will include training and job opportunities for those helped by the project.\n\nConstruction is due to begin in September this year, and the first homes are set to be completed in autumn 2025.\n\nIt was also confirmed the first phase of development will focus on \"creating high quality temporary accommodation that feels like home\", said the Duchy.\n\nBen Murphy, the Duchy's estate director, said Duchy is well-known for integrating high quality affordable housing into the new communities built on its land, and Prince William is determined to ensure that we continue to be part of the solution when it comes to the housing crisis.\"\n\nThe Prince of Wales became patron of the homelessness charity Centrepoint in 2004 and has tirelessly worked to provide support for those in need.\n\nHenry Meacock, St Petrocs charity's chief executive, added: \"With the Duchy of Cornwall, we believe we can deliver a truly exemplary project embedded in the local community which will provide a route for {"uri": "8119626027", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:29:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:29:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:29:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.marieclaire.com/celebrity/royals/prince-harry-emotional-about-prince-william-new-appointment/", "title": "Prince Harry Was Reportedly \"In Tears\" When He Learned That King Charles Gave Prince William a Role That, Had Harry Remained a Working Member of the Royal Family, Would Have Likely Been Given to Him", "body": "As Marie Claire reported yesterday, on the same day that Prince Harry arrived in the U.K. earlier this week, his father, King Charles, made Harry's brother, Prince William, the leader of the regiment that Harry once served in -- and new information is being reported that the move landed Harry in tears.\n\nOn Tuesday, the King announced that the role of Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps -- the regiment Harry served in during his service in Afghanistan -- would officially be passed to William. \"His Majesty the King will officially hand over the role of Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps to His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales,\" a statement from Buckingham Palace read. According to The Independent, had Harry not stepped back as a working member of the royal family (which he did alongside wife Meghan Markle in 2020), the role would have likely gone to Harry.\n\nThe timing of the announcement is iffy at best, and The Mirror reports that Harry got emotional and was \"in tears\" at hearing the news of William's appointment given by Charles -- no doubt exacerbated by Charles' apparent refusal to make time for his younger son while Harry was in the U.K. this week.\n\n\"King Charles' announcement that Prince Harry is being stripped of his role as Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps is a real kick in the teeth for the son who always felt marginalized and underrated,\" royal author Tom Quinn told The Mirror. \"What makes it much worse is that the role is being given to the very man who Harry sees as the cause of so many of his problems -- his brother. And the announcement was deliberately made during Harry's brief visit to the U.K. to have maximum impact -- it shows Harry that he really is no longer welcome.\"\n\nQuinn claimed that senior royals knew that the announcement would \"really hurt\" Harry: \"He is said to have been in tears when he heard,\" Quinn said. \"But they have decided the gloves are off and that Harry needs to realize that when you betray the family, you don't just escape the things you hated doing as a working royal. You also lose the things you loved.\"\n\nWilliam is expected to take over the role soon -- on May 13, this upcoming Monday.\n\nHarry remains extremely proud of his decade of service in the British Army, which included two tours in Afghanistan. Quinn added that \"Harry feels his time in the military was a rare happy time in his life when he was judged on his merits as a man, not on his merits as a member of the royal family,\" he said. \"Having always hated being the spare in terms of the succession, he now finds that one of the few important roles he had as the younger brother has now been handed over to the person Harry himself described as his nemesis. Harry cannot fail to get the message -- his last few ties to his old life are being cut, and he is being set adrift, permanently.\"\n\nReports have surfaced from royal experts Hugo Vickers and Arthur Edwards that the King could have made time to see Harry this week had he really wanted to, and from Charlotte Griffiths that William (as well as Queen Camilla) likely played a factor in Charles' And there was much speculation in the British media beforehand that the visit might offer an opportunity to see his father, who is being treated for cancer.\n\nHowever, Charles did not find time to meet his younger son over the two days, in part due to a garden party he was hosting at Buckingham Palace in London on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nNo royals attended the Service of Thanksgiving honoring Invictus at St. Paul's Cathedral, in London, which was the centerpiece of Harry's visit.\n\nHowever, Princess Diana's brother Charles Spencer and sister Jane Fellowes both attended and were seen hugging Harry in the pews at St. Paul's.\n\nThe post was viewed more than 273,000 times and liked over 8,300 times after it showed Prince Harry hugging uncle Spencer and aunt Fellowes.\n\nDuring the service, Harry gave a reading from Corinthians: \"Now there are varieties of gifts, with the same spirit and there are varieties of services, with the same lord, and there are varieties of activities, but it is the same god who activates all of them in everyone.\n\n\"To each is given the manifestation of the spirit of the common good.\"\n\nThe duke was flying solo at the service after Meghan Markle stayed home in California with their children, Prince Archie and Princess Lilibet.\n\nIt was always expected that no senior royals would turn up for the Invictus event, but many commentators had hoped to see Harry and Charles meet.\n\nBrand strategist and author Justine Castellon wrote on X: \"By snubbing the Invictus event, Charles and William inadvertently did Harry a favor. In their absence, Harry shines brighter, becoming the focal point of the news.\n\n\"It's heartwarming to see Earl Spencer demonstrate to the world that #PrinceHarry is still surrounded by family.\"\n\nAt Diana's funeral in 1997, Spencer addressed the princess during his eulogy to promise to look after Harry and Prince William: \"On behalf of your mother and sisters, I pledge that we, your blood family, will do all we can to continue the imaginative way in which you were steering these two exceptional young men so that their souls are not simply immersed by duty and tradition but can sing openly as you planned.\n\n\"We fully respect the heritage into which they have both been born and will always respect and encourage them in their royal role but we, like you, recognize the need for them to experience as many different aspects of life as possible to arm them spiritually and emotionally for the years ahead. Us Weekly described him as \"stunned but thrilled\" by the turnout, which is a sad reminder of the ongoing royal feud. The Duke of Sussex was there without Meghan Markle to celebrate because the security issues have not been resolved. The rest of his family, who were invited personally by Harry, decided that a garden party at Buckingham Palace just two miles away was far more important.\n\nIn a time of royal crisis with King Charles III and Kate Middleton battling cancer, a show of unity at Harry's Invictus Games event would not only have been a PR opportunity, but it might have also opened the lines of communication just a little bit more between Charles and his youngest son. He and Meghan aren't returning to their senior roles, but public appearances tied to their philanthropic work are missed. "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.the-star.co.ke/news/world/2024-05-08-harry-and-king-at-london-events-but-will-not-meet/", "title": "Harry and King at London events but will not meet", "body": "The Duke of Sussex has attended a service at St Paul's Cathedral in London during a brief visit to the UK.\n\nPrince Harry was speaking at the event to mark the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games, the sporting competition for injured service men and women he helped found.\n\nMeanwhile, the King, whose cancer treatment is ongoing, met members of the public at a Buckingham Palace garden party a little over two miles away.\n\nThe two are not scheduled to see each other while both are in London.\n\nThe duke's spokesman said the King's \"full programme\" prevented any meeting.\n\nA crowd gathered in the sunshine outside St Paul's to greet Prince Harry, the driving force behind the Invictus Games, who smiled and waved from the steps as he arrived.\n\nOnce inside, he gave a warm greeting to his uncle, Earl Spencer, who was sitting behind him in the cathedral.\n\nSpeaking in the church where his parents were married, Prince Harry gave a Bible reading from Corinthians that emphasised different people have different gifts and strengths.\n\nAnother reading from Isaiah talked of stopping \"the pointing of the finger, the speaking of evil\".\n\nIt was a very traditional service, with hymns, psalms and Bible readings, under the chandeliers and frescoes of the cathedral dome.\n\nThere was also an emotional reading of a poem about the positive impact of the Invictus Games by Michelle Turner, captain of the UK's team in Sydney in 2018.\n\nAs he left, Prince Harry got another enthusiastic reception from the crowd outside, who cheered him as he pulled away in a black Range Rover.\n\nHe has been in legal battles over security during visits to the UK, but there were lines of City of London police here seeing him safely away.\n\nThe duke, who now lives in California, last saw the King in person shortly after his February announcement that he was being treated for an unspecified form of cancer.\n\nThe King has since returned to some public duties but is continuing to receive medical care.\n\nOn Wednesday he was seen removing his top hat and waving it in the air as a crowd greeted him by singing the national anthem at Buckingham Palace.\n\nPrince Harry is also not expected to meet the Prince or Princess of Wales - who is also being treated for cancer - while in the UK.\n\nOn Tuesday, a spokesperson for the duke said: \"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme.\n\n\"The duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nOn Tuesday, the duke attended an Invictus Games summit in London, where he told delegates: \"Sometimes you... look back and go 'Look at what we've done'.\n\n\"But also given the state of the world, there is so much more to do and I think a lot of uncertainty - but what we've created is a global community.\"\n\nPrince Harry is not being joined by the Duchess of Sussex for this visit, but his wife is scheduled to meet him in Nigeria, where he is due to travel after his stop in London.\n\nThe couple were invited by Nigeria's chief of defence staff after they met at the Invictus Games held last year in Germany.", "source": {"uri": At the service at St Paul's Cathedral today, he arrived to cheers from the gathered on-lookers. T&C contributing editor Victoria Murphy was on the scene to capture the moment:\n\nWhile no members of the royal family will be joining Prince Harry today, members of Princess Diana's family, including her brother, Charles Spencer, and her sister, Lady Jane Fellowes, were in attendance at the event. In addition Harry's cousins Lara Spencer, Louis Spencer, and George McCorquodale were also spotted entering the cathedral.\n\nSince moving to the U.S., Prince Harry has remained close with the Spencer side of his family. In September 2022, when Harry and Meghan Markle were back in the UK for Queen Elizabeth's funeral, they took a trip to Althorp, Princess Diana's childhood home, spent time with his uncle and his aunts, and visited Diana's final resting place. Plus, in March 2023 Diana's sisters, Lady Jane and Lady Sarah McCorquodale, were reportedly in attendance at Princess Lilibet's christening.\n\nElsewhere in London, King Charles hosted the first Garden Party of the year at Buckingham Palace. He was joined by many other senior working royals, including Queen Camilla, Princess Anne, Prince Edward, and Sophie, Duchess of Edinburgh.\n\nA spokesperson for the Duke of Sussex told T&C that Harry won't see Charles while he's in town this week. \"It unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme. The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon,\" the spokesperson said. "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/world/516350/prince-harry-and-king-charles-at-london-events-but-will-not-meet", "title": "Prince Harry and King Charles at London events but will not meet", "body": "The Duke of Sussex has attended a service at St Paul's Cathedral in London during a brief visit to the United Kingdom.\n\nPrince Harry was speaking at the event to mark the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games, the sporting competition for injured service men and women he helped found.\n\nMeanwhile, the King, whose cancer treatment is ongoing, met members of the public at a Buckingham Palace garden party a little over two miles away.\n\nThe two are not scheduled to see each other while both are in London.\n\nThe duke's spokesman said the King's \"full programme\" prevented any meeting.\n\nA crowd gathered in the sunshine outside St Paul's to greet Prince Harry, the driving force behind the Invictus Games, who smiled and waved from the steps as he arrived.\n\nOnce inside, he gave a warm greeting to his uncle, Earl Spencer, who was sitting behind him in the cathedral.\n\nSpeaking in the church where his parents were married, Prince Harry gave a Bible reading from Corinthians that emphasised different people have different gifts and strengths.\n\nAnother reading from Isaiah talked of stopping \"the pointing of the finger, the speaking of evil\".\n\nIt was a very traditional service, with hymns, psalms and Bible readings, under the chandeliers and frescoes of the cathedral dome.\n\nThere was also an emotional reading of a poem about the positive impact of the Invictus Games by Michelle Turner, captain of the UK's team in Sydney in 2018.\n\nThe prince, who now lives in California, last saw the King in person shortly after his February announcement that he was being treated for an unspecified form of cancer.\n\nThe King has since returned to some public duties but is continuing to receive medical care.\n\nOn Wednesday, he was seen removing his top hat and waving it in the air as a crowd greeted him by singing the national anthem at Buckingham Palace.\n\nPrince Harry is also not expected to meet the Prince or Princess of Wales - who is also being treated for cancer - while in the UK.\n\nOn Tuesday, a spokesperson for the duke said: \"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme.\n\n\"The duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nOn Tuesday, the duke attended an Invictus Games summit in London, where he told delegates: \"Sometimes you... look back and go 'Look at what we've done'.\n\n\"But also given the state of the world, there is so much more to do and I think a lot of uncertainty - but what we've created is a global community.\"\n\nPrince Harry is not being joined by the Duchess of Sussex for this visit, but his wife is scheduled to meet him in Nigeria, where he is due to travel after his stop in London.\n\nThe couple were invited by Nigeria's and surprise, even shock, when no such get-together happened.\n\nAs Prince Harry's newly appointed British spokesman explained on Tuesday: 'In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the Duke will meet with his father while in the UK this week, it, unfortunately, will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme.\n\nThe Duke, he continued, 'is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon'.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex meets members of the public at The Invictus Games Foundation 10th Anniversary Service at St Paul's Cathedral on Wednesday\n\nRichard Eden says: 'From everything I hear, there will be no rapprochement between the Sussexes and the royals until Harry and Meghan have said sorry for the distress that they have caused'\n\nFriends of King Charles and Queen Camilla who I have spoken to are not in the least bit surprised, however.\n\nThe 75-year-old King has met his younger son only once since he was diagnosed with an unnamed form of cancer more than three months ago - and that meeting lasted no more than 30 minutes.\n\nHarry had dashed straight over from his home in California following the announcement of Charles's illness - but he was soon heading back to the airport following the briefest of meetings with the King.\n\nWhy might His Majesty have chosen not to see his younger son this week?\n\n'He doesn't need the drama in his life,' explained one of the friends.\n\n'Harry and Meghan have brought him, and the rest of the family, nothing but worries over the past few years.'\n\nKing Charles has long wanted to use his position to make an impact.\n\nFriends of the King and Queen have told the Mail's Richard Eden that the monarch decided not to meet Harry this week because 'he 'doesn't need the drama in his life' from a bitter son\n\nHe founded the Prince's Trust in 1976 to help vulnerable young people get their lives on track. Later, he encouraged traditional architecture and became a passionate advocate of protecting the environment - just a few examples of his many interests.\n\n'In some ways, this might sound odd, but the cancer diagnosis has given His Majesty even more energy,' another friend tells me.\n\nCharles and Camilla are all smiles attending a Royal Garden Party at Buckingham Palace (above and below) on Wednesday - the same day Prince Harry was just two miles away at St Paul's Cathedral\n\nIt's been a bittersweet week for Harry, returning to the warmth of veterans at The Invictus Games Foundation's tenth Anniversary Service at St Paul's Cathedral - but given the cold shoulder by his own father and brother (below in 2014)\n\n'He spent decades waiting to be King, of course, and realises that his time might be very limited.'\n\n'So, he's determined to make as much difference as he can - as soon as he can.\n\n'Frankly speaking, Harry and Meghan are a painful distraction that he could do without.'\n\nThe King returned to his public engagements last week - with a visit to a cancer centre - even though he has not yet completed his own treatment.\n\nAnd the Queen gave an insight into her husband's sense of urgency when she told a guest at a Buckingham Palace reception: 'I think he was really thrilled to be out.'\n\nShe added, tellingly: 'I've been trying to hold him back.'\n\nIt is understood that the Sussexes are yet to make an apology for their highly personal and very public criticism of the Royal Family.\n\nIt is said that, in private, they continue to insist that they are the ones who deserve an apology.\n\nFrom everything I hear, there will be no rapprochement between the Sussexes and the royals until Harry and Meghan have said sorry for the distress that they have caused.\n\nMegan and Harry (seen here with Charles at Trooping The Colour in 2018) are now 'a painful distraction that he could do without'\n\nI understand that The King finds it particularly hard to forgive the comments Harry made in his explosive memoir, Spare - in which the Duke portrayed his step-mother, Queen Camilla, as a 'villain' who left him as a 'body in the street' in her desire to rehabilitate her own image.\n\nIt was no coincidence that one of the Queen's closest and most discreet confidantes, the Marchioness of Lansdowne, chose to speak last year about the pain that Harry's comments had caused.\n\n'Of course it bothers her, of course it hurts,' Lady Lansdowne said then.\n\n'Her [Camilla's] philosophy is always, \"Don't make a thing of it and it will settle down - least said, soonest mended\".'\n\nUntil Harry apologises for that hurt - at least in private, if not in public - meetings with his father might be hard to come by.\n\nSign up for Richard Eden's royal newsletter. magazine.\n\n\"That side of the family seems to be better relations.\"\n\nTessa went on to slam the viewpoint that Harry has no family, instead insisting: \"While all the focus is on Harry and Meghan not having any family or relations, he clearly does have relations with the Spencers.\"\n\nShe then referenced Harry's bombshell memoir Spare, where he spoke about his two aunts and uncle being there when he and Meghan visited Diana's grave.\n\nPrince Harry and Earl Spencer's close bond was evident at Princess Diana's funeral in September 1997 when Charles walked alongside his young nephews behind his sister's coffin.\n\nHe raised concerns at the time about the then young royals walking in the funeral procession, and later went on to describe it as the \"most horrifying half hour of my life.\"\n\nIn an interview with BBC Radio 4's Today programme, he revealed that he still had nightmares from the \"harrowing\" experience twenty years on from the sad occasion.\n\nHowever, he noted that it must be a \"million times worse\" for Prince Harry and William.\n\nIn a touching eulogy, Charles publicly vowed to protect his nephews.]\n\nHe said: \"I pledge that we, your blood family, will do all we can to continue the imaginative and loving way in which you were steering these two exceptional young men so that their souls are not simply immersed by duty and tradition, but can sing openly as you planned.\"\n\nHe continued: \"We fully respect the heritage into which they have both been born and will always respect and encourage them in their royal role.\n\n\"But we, like you, recognise the need for them to experience as many different aspects of life as possible to arm them spiritually and emotionally for the years ahead. I know you would have expected nothing less from us.\"\n\nWhile Earl Spencer isn't often seen in public with his nephews, he's been there to support them during several events - namely involving those to commemorate his late sister.\n\nIn 2006, Charles joined Prince Harry and William during the unveiling of a memorial fountain dedicated to Diana at Hyde Park in London.\n\nThen, in 2021, they were all seen together in public as they unveiled a new statue of the Princess in the gardens of Buckingham Palace on what would have been her 60th birthday.\n\nEarl Spencer has also attended Kate Middleton and Prince William's wedding in April 2011, and was spotted again when Harry and Meghan Markle wed in 2018.\n\nEarl Spencer recently revealed how he underwent the same therapy for trauma as Prince Harry.\n\nIn his Memoir, A Very Private School, Charles explained how he's been treated for physical, sexual and emotional abuse he suffered while at Northamptonshire's Maidwell Hall boarding school between 1972 and 1977.\n\n\"I have EMDR, which is a form of therapy for PTSD,\" he said.\n\nIt comes after Prince Harry revealed in 2001 that he'd used the same form of PTSD treatment.\n\nSpeaking on an episode of his AppleTV series, The Me You Can't See, he noted how he was using EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitisation and Reprocessing) for four or five memories that he still found disturbing from his childhood.\n\nAlongside his therapist Sanja Oakley, he explained: \"EMDR is always something that I wanted to try and that was one of the varieties of different forms of healing or curing that I was willing to experiment with.\n\n\"I never would have been open to that had I not put in the work and the therapy that I've done over the years.\"", "source": {"uri": The Duke of Sussex has finally jetted back to British soil for an Invictus Games event, leaving Meghan Markle and their children, Archie and Lilibet, back in California.\n\nLanding on Tuesday, May 7, speculation was rife about whether Harry would catch up with King Charles. However, hopes for a father-son catch-up have been dashed. A spokesperson for Prince Harry has confirmed that there will be no meeting due to the King's packed schedule.\n\nThe statement from Harry's camp stated: \"It unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full programme. The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nDespite expectations of a reunion, top Royal expert and former BBC roya editor Jennie Bond told OK! that the missed opportunity suggests a deep rift, saying, \"we can deduce that their relationship is terminally damaged\". {"uri": "8117751513", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:37:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:37:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:37:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.thedailybeast.com/queen-camilla-is-the-real-reason-king-charles-wont-see-harry-friend-says", "title": "Queen Camilla Is the Real Reason King Charles Won't See Harry, Friend Says", "body": "King Charles decided not to meet his son Prince Harry in London this week because of Harry's \"cruel\" remarks about his wife, Queen Camilla, in his memoir, Spare, a friend of Charles and Camilla has told The Daily Beast.\n\nObservers had thought that father and son could have met today, Wednesday, especially as both had events within just a couple of miles of each other -- a ceremony to mark the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games for Harry, and the first Buckingham Palace garden party of the year for Charles. But Harry released a statement saying Charles was too busy to see him, with the palace a couple of hours later saying Charles was making Prince William the head of Harry's old regiment. Harry's U.K. trip has fast become a snub pile-up.\n\nIn Spare, Harry said Camilla \"sacrificed me on her personal PR altar,\" and described her as \"dangerous.\"\n\nIn remarks to Anderson Cooper on the show 60 Minutes to promote the book, which is estimated to have made Harry some $27 million, Harry said: \"With a family built on hierarchy, and with her on the way to being queen consort, there was going to be people or bodies left in the street.\"\n\nHe also described his stepmother as a \"villain\" and the \"third person in the marriage,\" echoing his mother's controversial interview with Martin Bashir in 1995, when Diana said there were \"three of us in the marriage.\"\n\n\"Harry has made things very difficult for himself by saying such cruel and hurtful things about Camilla,\" the friend told The Daily Beast. \"Charles loves his sons, but he also loves his wife. The last few months have made it very clear how important she is; she has been the one propping up the whole edifice.\n\n\"Harry has made it very clear, very publicly, that he despises her. He has forced Charles to choose, which was a very silly thing to do because Camilla and he both chose each other a long time ago.\n\n\"William had his reservations but he accepted his father's choice and got on with it. Harry made a different decision, and one of the inevitable consequences of publicly calling your stepmother cruel names is that it becomes difficult for you to see your father.\"\n\nAnother source, a friend of William and Kate's, quipped: \"It is hardly surprising that Charles didn't invite Harry round for tea and a scone. He did, after all, portray his wife as an evil, calculating, bitch in the biggest selling book since the Bible.\" [In fact, Spare broke records for being the fastest-selling non-fiction book but it is not, yet at least, certified as the biggest selling non-fiction book of all time.]\n\nAnother source, a former Buckingham Palace staffer, said, \"As far as the palace is concerned, the further away that Harry and Meghan are from Buckingham Palace the better. Look how distracting Harry's visit has been this week. The media should be talking about the king's return to work, instead we are talking about a 39 year old man's daddy issues. If Harry thinks he can drop in for a cuppa at Clarence House whenever he happens to be changing planes in London, that would encourage him to come here more often, which is the exact opposite of what the institution typically wants from exiled family members. The whole point of being exiled is that you are out of sight and out of mind.\"\n\nThe courtier also said that Harry's statement saying his father had declined to meet him was \"childish.\"\n\nIn the statement, Harry's spokesperson said: \"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the Duke will meet with his father while in the U.K. this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full program. Everything is always someone else's fault. Even Harry must know the reason a meeting isn't happening is not due to Charles' 'full program' -- it's because Harry sold out his own family.\"\n\nRichard Kay, the well-connected Daily Mail journalist said that both Camilla and William \"would have viewed the prospect of a meeting between the king and Harry deeply troubling.\"\n\nAs The Daily Beast has reported, William has no interest in renewing his relationship with his brother.\n\nIn another clear expression of the different ways that the king's two sons are treated by their father, just hours after the revelation that Charles and Harry would not meet, Buckingham Palace announced a new military role for Prince William as Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps. The position will be bestowed on William during a rare joint engagement with his father next week.\n\nPrior to his departure from the royal family, the role had been earmarked for Harry, who was a But Harry released a statement saying Charles was too busy to see him, with the palace a couple of hours later saying Charles was making Prince William the head of Harry's old regiment. Harry's U.K. trip has fast become a snub pile-up.\n\nIn Spare, Harry said Camilla \"sacrificed me on her personal PR altar,\" and described her as \"dangerous.\"\n\nIn remarks to Anderson Cooper on the show 60 Minutes to promote the book, which is estimated to have made Harry some $27 million, Harry said: \"With a family built on hierarchy, and with her on the way to being queen consort, there was going to be people or bodies left in the street.\"\n\nHe also described his stepmother as a \"villain\" and the \"third person in the marriage,\" echoing his mother's controversial interview with Martin Bashir in 1995, when Diana said there were \"three of us in the marriage.\"\n\nKing Says He's Too Busy With Work to See Harry During London Trip\n\n\"Harry has made things very difficult for himself by saying such cruel and hurtful things about Camilla,\" the friend told The Daily Beast. \"Charles loves his sons, but he also loves his wife. The last few months have made it very clear how important she is; she has been the one propping up the whole edifice.\n\n\"Harry has made it very clear, very publicly, that he despises her. He has forced Charles to choose, which was a very silly thing to do because Camilla and he both chose each other a long time ago.\n\n\"William had his reservations but he accepted his father's choice and got on with it. Harry made a different decision, and one of the inevitable consequences of publicly calling your stepmother cruel names is that it becomes difficult for you to see your father.\"\n\nAnother source, a friend of William and Kate's, quipped: \"It is hardly surprising that Charles didn't invite Harry round for tea and a scone. He did, after all, portray his wife as an evil, calculating, bitch in the biggest selling book since the Bible.\" [In fact, Spare broke records for being the fastest-selling non-fiction book but it is not, yet at least, certified as the biggest selling non-fiction book of all time.]\n\nAnother source, a former Buckingham Palace staffer, said, \"As far as the palace is concerned, the further away that Harry and Meghan are from Buckingham Palace the better. Look how distracting Harry's visit has been this week. The media should be talking about the king's return to work, instead we are talking about a 39 year old man's daddy issues. If Harry thinks he can drop in for a cuppa at Clarence House whenever he happens to be changing planes in London, that would encourage him to come here more often, which is the exact opposite of what the institution typically wants from exiled family members. The whole point of being exiled is that you are out of sight and out of mind.\"\n\nThe courtier also said that Harry's statement saying his father had declined to meet him was \"childish.\"\n\nIn the statement, Harry's spokesperson said: \"In response to the many inquiries and continued speculation on whether or not the Duke will meet with his father while in the U.K. this week, it unfortunately will not be possible due to His Majesty's full program. The Duke of course is understanding of his father's diary of commitments and various other priorities and hopes to see him soon.\"\n\nThe source said, \"It was classic Harry -- childish and petulant foot-stamping. Everything is always someone else's fault. Even Harry must know the reason a meeting isn't happening is not due to Charles' 'full program' -- it's because Harry sold out his own family.\"\n\nRichard Kay, the well-connected Daily Mail journalist said that both Camilla and William \"would have viewed the prospect of a meeting between the king and Harry deeply troubling.\"\n\nAs The Daily Beast has reported, William has no interest in renewing his relationship with his brother.\n\nIn another clear expression of the different ways that the king's two sons are treated by their father, just hours after the revelation that Charles and Harry would not meet, Buckingham Palace announced a new military role for Prince William as Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps. The position will be bestowed on William during a rare joint engagement with his father next week.\n\nPrior to his departure from the royal family, the role had been earmarked for Harry, who was a member of the regiment.\n\nBuckingham Palace did not return a request for comment on whether Harry's remarks about Camilla were a factor in his father not meeting him this week.\n\nRead more at The Daily Beast.\n\nGet the Daily Beast's biggest scoops and scandals delivered right to your inbox. {"uri": "8119818648", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:30:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:30:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:29:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://honey.nine.com.au/royals/why-earl-spencer-will-never-give-up-on-prince-harry/35f56fde-b58c-42d2-8219-9cb2d9a28066", "title": "Why Earl Spencer will never give up on Prince Harry", "body": "When the Duke of Sussex flew back to Britain for the 10th anniversary of the Invictus Games, the narrative was more or less set before he arrived.\n\nHe would be alone, here briefly for a church service, with his wife and children far away and the Royal Family busy on public engagements elsewhere.\n\nAnd so it proved, initially. With a smile and a wave, he walked up the steps of St Paul's Cathedral as a lone figure, his staff and security making their way in slightly away from the cameras.\n\nREAD MORE: Prince Harry arrives to cheers for Invictus Games service\n\nInside, though, it was a different story: the Spencer family rode to the very public rescue.\n\nHis uncle Earl Spencer and aunt Lady Jane Fellowes were waiting with hugs, three of Prince Harry's Spencer cousins behind them.\n\n\"Thanks for coming,\" Prince Harry told the Earl, looking sincere as he pulled back from the maternal family embrace. He blew a kiss and waved at others.\n\nREAD MORE: Prince William's new title 'quite a snub' for Harry\n\nThe Invictus veterans and competitors always give the Prince a warm welcome, but the presence of some family members was a visible boost to his spirits.\n\nIt was enough to inspire The Sun front page to declare: \"Diana's Family Backs Harry.\"\n\n\"Now that Harry has left the Royal family, the Spencers have laid claim to him again,\" said Ingrid Seward, editor of Majesty magazine.\n\nThe invitation, and its acceptance, brought the rare spotlight onto the side of the Prince's family he has valued over the years, a quiet but constant part of his adult life.\n\nHe has mentioned them only occasionally, sparing them from the truth-telling pages of his memoir save for in the acknowledgements where he offered \"stand out thanks to my mother's siblings for their love, support, time and perspective\".\n\nHis paternal family - so well-covered throughout the book, his Netflix series, and his interviews - were not thanked.\n\nREAD MORE: Emirates pilot reveals amazing perks of the job\n\nThe King, it is claimed, was invited to the Invictus Games service. The Prince and Princess of Wales were sent invitations, but were not able to attend.\n\nThe King was at a garden party a few miles away, his first since his diagnosis with cancer. Prince William conducted an investiture in Windsor on the same day and the Princess, as is well known, is out of the public eye during a course of preventative chemotherapy.\n\nInside the cathedral, those watching Prince Harry noted his relatively newfound confidence in delivering his reading, and the animation with which he turned around in his seat to chat to the Spencers.\n\nThey have rarely appeared in public with him over the years, but have remained present - not least in their roles as the closest remaining link to his late mother.\n\nHis aunts in particular have been there in the shadows, should one care to look closely.\n\nIn a 2017 television interview to mark her engagement, Meghan Markle said: \"I think in being able to meet his aunts ... I'm able to, in some way, know a part of her [Diana] through them and, of course, through him. And it's incredibly special.\"\n\nLady Jane, the middle of the three sisters, gave a reading at Prince Harry and Meghan's wedding, and is said to have been one of the first people introduced to a newborn Prince Archie.\n\nBoth Lady Jane and Lady Sarah were included in the formal photographs from Prince Archie's christening.\n\nREAD MORE: The products a former beauty editor will buy again (and again)\n\nAt the Invictus Games service, Prince Harry was seen deep in conversation with both the Earl and Lady Jane, beaming at them as they waited for the service to start.\n\nThe venue, St Paul's, was evocative in itself, where Lady Diana Spencer's siblings watched in 1981 as she married Prince Charles and became the new Princess of Wales.\n\nSixteen years later, with the 12-year-old Prince Harry watching on, Earl Spencer rocked the establishment with a eulogy in which he called his sister the \"most hunted person of the modern age\".\n\nAddressing her \"beloved boys\", he said then: \"I pledge that we, your blood family, will do all we can to continue the imaginative and loving way in which you were steering these two exceptional young men, so that their souls are not simply immersed by duty and tradition, but can sing openly as you planned.\"\n\nHe has since passed occasional comment on the Royal family. In 2002, in an interview with The Guardian, he is quoted as remarking: \"What I can say is that they may not be encouraged to stay in touch with their mother's side of the family.\"\n\nIn 2017, on Radio 4, he claimed he had been \"lied to\" about Princes William and Harry \"wanting\" to walk behind their mother's coffin.\n\nThis time, his appearance was low-key. Before the service, it was rumoured that all three of Diana's siblings would attend, but Lady Sarah McCorquodale was not seen. Her son George, 39, was there along with Lady Lara and Louis Spencer, Viscount Althorp.\n\nThe Earl's only public comment was made afterwards on social media site X. \"I hope my father would have approved that I wore his Royal Scots Greys regimental cufflinks at \u2066the moving celebration of 10 years of \u2066@WeAreInvictus\u2069 at @StPaulsLondon\u2069 yesterday,\" he said.\n\nIngrid Seward, author of recent royal biography My Mother and I, notes that the late Diana, Princess of Wales was \"proud of her Spencer heritage as is Viscount Althorp and as is Harry\".\n\n\"He is close to what he calls his 'red aunts',\" she says, a reference to the family hair colour.\n\nThe Duke of Sussex, as he left St Paul's, had a spring in his step. Launching into a walkabout, he fell into the tried-and-tested pattern of handshakes and snippets of conversation: \"Very nice to meet you. How are you? Have you come on holiday?\"\n\nWhen one member of the public told him they were in London for a wedding, he turned to point at St Paul's and joked: \"Not in here?\"\n\nShown the two cameras held by another, he exclaimed: \"You've got two cameras? That doesn't even make sense!\"\n\nHe and the Duchess will fly to Nigeria for a three-day trip, also based around military veterans, arriving on Friday.\n\nThe image, as Harry leaves Britain once again, is still of a divided family.\n\nThe Royal family, as ever, will remain silent. The Spencers, by turning up, have said it all.\n\n\u00a9 Telegraph Media Group Limited 2024", "source": {"uri": "honey.nine.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "honey.nine.com.au"}, "authors": [],
